39487607.review:
[h1]Un'avventura mostruosamente divertente![/h1]

Solitamente i porting da console portatile o da mobile risultano sempre in giochi che, giocati su pc o su uno schermo grande non rendono o risultano macchinosi. Gurumin, nonostante alcuni limiti tecnici, fa da eccezione. Originariamente lasciato su PSP e Windows nel 2006, portato poi più recentemente su 3Ds è stato poi rilasciato su Steam con un ottimo porting. La trama, molto semplice, si basa sulla struttura del viaggio dell'eroe di Christopher Vogler; l'eroe, una piccola ragazzina a cui potremmo dare noi il nome, si ritroverà in un mondo straordinario in cui affronterà diverse prove per accrescere i suoi poteri fino a superare la prova finale per poi tornare nel mondo ordinario. Nonostante certi elementi del gameplay action-rpg sentano ormai il peso degli anni ed il fatto che fossero sviluppati per console portatile non di certo aiuta, il piccolo titolo risulta estremamente divertente da giocare e da scoprire. Per completare il gioco al 100% servono un paio di run da circa 14/15 ore l'una. Considerato il poco tempo che mi rimane ormai per giocare ho deciso di portare a termine una sola delle 2 run completando il più possibile. Adotta come molti titoli studiati per le portatili lo stile grafico "Chibi" con personaggi caricaturali che, integrati in un mondo incredibilmente colorato che, nonostante gli evidenti limiti tecnici risultano piacevoli da esplorare ricordando i tempi andati. Nonostante questi limiti tecnici passabili ne è presente uno che non posso astenermi dal considerare che è la telecamera che, in più di una situazione si trova mal posizionata rispetto all'ambiente circostante. In pillole è una piccola e divertente perla neanche tanto breve che è assolutamente consigliata per chi vuole intraprendere una semplice e neanche tanto breve ma divertente avventura dal sapore fiabesco.

N.B. è assolutamente consigliato giocare il titolo con un Joypad.

39370933.review:
This game is not worth the full price, ever. Not even half, not even 75% off.
The input controls are queued. Meaning you will lose control of your character for a few seconds as the game struggles to finish the short chain of commands you pressed earlier.
Special moves read input from the last 5 seconds, you will more often than not use the wrong special moves when all you wanted to do was normally stab something.
Voice acting for the main character is TERRIBLE in both the English and Japanese version. There is 0 heart involved and next to no emotion, and considering you hear her voice 99% of the time, it starts to get annoying.
Many sound effects that are not key to combat are omitted.

Its basically a game you give a toddler to play for his/her very first experience with games.

38509017.review:
Forgive me if this is not professional looking, I am not one to do reviews. But for this game, I'd like to tell about the game and help spread word of it.

Gurumin is a light-hearted and colorful adventure that was first released on the Christmas of 2004.
In this adventure, you play as Parin. The setting is Teise Town, where you move here to live with your grandfather while your  parents travel abroad for excavations. You get acquanted with the people in the town and then meet a girl who introduces herself and her brother as Pino and Puku, respectively. They then show you the way to the fabled Monster Village, where your adventure beings!

As you explore the world, you fight the villainous group of people known as the Phantoms and their minions. In order to do so, you've been granted with the legendary drill. The drill has a variety of moves and powers that you can learn/collect during the course of the game, so combat never gets dull. You've also got a few movement options, including dashing that makes you invulnerable for a moment and being able to hone in on enemies in the air and dash at them.

Parin controls very well... if you have a gamepad that is. I am aware that the keyboard + mouse is from what I hear not well laid out. This can be a slight issue when you need to do some tight jumps.  I'd reccomend being able to play with a gamepad if you can, though this goes for basically any 3D platforming game.

The drill has techniques that you can purchase later in the game. They are varied and you can use them in numerous situations. Also avaiable to unlock throughout the game are elemental parts. They can be used in puzzles to solve and each element has their own uses for taking out the bad guys.

Phantoms: they are the bad guys, and come in all shapes and sizes. When you start out, they may seem simple, but later on throughout the game, they mix up their tactics and become very crafty. Adapting to their various weapons and such is important to be able to defeat them. It also adds a lot of variety to combat, as well.

There is a bunch of colorful worlds in Gurumin to explore. Potato Ruins; a tan labyrinth where there's always a hidden treasure. Radish Woods; a serene place with running rivers. Spinach Caverns; a cool underground maze that's hosting it's own surprises. Pimento Mountain; Beautiful snowtops that accompany narrow footing and walkways. And more...

Along the game, you can purchase/collect hats that give numerous benefits, too. Examples such as more damage dealt, more money earned, and increased defense. Most of the hats look great, even if some didn't rub me the right way. [spoiler]Though I am no fashion desinger...[/spoiler]

I love this game's soundtrack a lot; the tracks are varied in their tone and mood, and it also compliments the world's setting. They just bend together to form an atmosphere that's not really like any game I've played before.  Seriously, you will not find another game that has this kind of art direction anywhere else.

The story is something that I didn't want to talk about beyond the introduction part of the game. Despite the exterior of this game would lead you to believe, it has a very well written story for a platformer. I was honestly taken by surprised of the quality it had.

Gurumin is one of the best games from the 2000s that I cannot reccomend enough. It is 10 dollars well spent, and during the Steam Winter Sale going on right now, it's only 3.49. 

I loved this game, and I hope you can too. :)

It's kind of sad to give this a "No, I don't recommend this game".

It's starts off nice enough, but... the controls just kill it. The camera is useless, and when the game is trying to make you 3D-platform it's just random guessing. You get special attacks, but some of them are directed -- and you can't really make them go into any specific direction, if you can make them go off at all. No big deal vs. trashmobs most of the time, but bossfights are harder than they need to be. Downlevelling the weapon when you take damage doesn't exactly help either.

And there are other annoying details. Like why does the shop not tell you what an item upgrade will do? These things are expensive...

Talking about expensive, "recharging" the weapon level and maybe filling up the basic heal items (cookies and chocolate) either costs a good deal of money between levels, or a lot of time spent going to earlier levels to fill up on stuff. There is really no need to artificially drag out playtime like this.

I wasn't impressed at first but once I progressed a bit more I couldn't put it down. The assumption that the game was too easy was pretty soon ended as I got to the later levels. To start with you have beginner and normal difficulties, with 3 more to unlock later on. I'm approaching the end of my first playthrough on normal, then I am going to do the beginner ones on my new game+ save, which is a very handy feature. For the first time in a long time, I went on a nostalgia trip with the ragequits and general frustrations caused by mini games and levels you'd get mad at as a kid (Spyro, Mario, Banjo Kazooie, we've all been there and it's great to feel it again).

The game reminds me of a mixture of Zelda (puzzles, dungeon crawling), Mario (platforming, collectables, overworld/level selection) and somewhat of My Neighbour Totoro for the general theme and aesthetic. Highly recommended if you like platforming games reminiscent of the early 2000's PS2 and N64 era.

I cannot imagine the game being played without a controller, especially if you want to play the harder difficulties for 100% completion, which is very difficult to do regardless.

34031925.review:
Love this game; the title is a give-away to how charming and innocent this game is. You're a young girl and are attempting to help your monster friends save their home. And reclaim lost furniture.

What carries this game is its charm; there's something likable about the characters and setting. It feels "Studio Ghibli-ish"; those that know the studio and have watched a few of their movies know exactly what I mean. There's a child-like whimsical nature encapsulated in the experience which the character designs, music, art style, and the totality of the visual helps convey. It makes for an entertaining experience everytime you boot it up; but that just might be me since I believe unique visual flairs to titles add to the experience and make them uniquely their own. This is one of those titles that people would place in that, "I would enjoy a cartoon series or short episodes of this being made" because what's here is fantastic.

The game itself is no slouch: whilst clearly targetted at children its still quality. It's on the easier side, but you'll still see the game over screen a few times and get damaged plenty, especially when you're attempting to get used to the game during the initial stages. The title is a mixture of platformers, light puzzle game, but is mostly a 1 button fighter with a few special moves and a drill that can be charged in battle. The charge is required against most enemies as they have armor, and the armor needs to be obliterated through a charged attack. You have an attack button, a dodge button, and a jump button. Simple.

My only complaint is the inclusion of the critical system in the game. At the top of the screen there is a bar and musical notes coming from the left and right side of the bar meeting in the middle. If you attack anything when the musical notes meet in the middle of the bar, you get a critical hit. Critical hits build up your drill's power and inflict more damage. The mechanic is interesting, but you will never realistically be stopping your attacks to time hits better. As it stands, criticals are incidental more than anything, as no one stops in the middle of striking opponents to get the timing down properly. It's like telling you you can juggle during matrix fights-its impractical. It's a superfluous mechanic.

Also worth noting is the weak sauce that is some of the "worlds" having levels that are just mirror versions of previous levels. Feels like padding and lazy as hell. It's not a lot of levels, and some are interesting, but still worth noting.

I'd place this game in the same categories as some of the Kirby Titles and Starfy: games that look to have a certain target market but bely an experience that can be enjoyed by all. Although the comparison is a little unfair, as the aforementioned franchises tend to have titles that usually lack any semblance of a challenge. This game may be targetted at younger audiences but it will still trip you up here and there. Additionally, the plot has depth that you otherwise wouldn't expect.

All in all, recommended. The game isn't particularly *amazing* or anything PHENOMENAL, but it has so much charm and the totality of the package makes for an enjoyable experience. The ending was bitter sweet for me as I wanted to see more of these characters and wished for it to continue. You get a solid game with characterization reminiscent of a child's movie that adults can enjoy even moreso than children due to its innocence that is lost on those that lack the ability to place nostalgic value on it.

33893576.review:
La prima cosa che coglie l'attenzione del giocatore (in senso negativo, purtroppo) è la grafica.. abbastanza datata (ricorda molto Ape Escape). Però ci sta, il gioco è alquanto vecchiotto, c'era da immaginarselo.
In secondo luogo, lo stile di movimento : è la prima volta che ho a che fare con una simile tipologia di comandi, e mi ci ritrovo maledettamente male. Sarà che sono ancora un incapace e non ho preso la mano, però, sheesh, è laidamente scomodo muovere e controllare il personaggio in questa maniera.
Un ultimo punto negativo del titolo sono i doppiaggi inglesi : personalmente, trovo che non rendano al 100%. Ci sono un paio di doppiatori buoni, ma il resto del cast, a mio dire, non rende altrettanto bene. Fortunatamente, esistono i file per i doppiaggi originali giapponesi, rovistando un po' tra le Discussioni di Steam si riescono a trovare.

Detto questo, passiamo ai lati positivi : anzitutto lo stile di potenziamento dell'arma. Decisamente molto innovativo nel suo genere, e funziona bene. Mi piace l'idea che la musica di sottofondo sia parte integrante delle battaglie.
In secondo luogo, le mosse speciali, la loro acquisizione e la loro attivazione. Anche questo punto è molto innovativo nel suo genere e rende bene. Non c'è uno stereotipico "Skill Tree" da cui ottenere le abilità. Qui ottieni nuovi pezzi che ti permettono di sbloccare tali mosse, e dovrai attivarle destrandoti tra movimenti ed attacchi in simultanea.

In definitiva : Gurumin implementa innovazioni nello stereotipico modo di giocare ai RPG sotto molti aspetti. A mio dire è diverso da tutti gli altri e vale la pena di provarlo per tutti gli amanti degli RPG (giapponesi e non), vale tutto il suo prezzo (se in sconto, ancora meglio).

29025161.review:
With first impressions in mind, it may be hard to decide if buying the game would be worth it. Certainly I was not the only one that felt the same way after reading some of the reviews on this game. After choosing to buy it, there was no regrets to be felt as the game progressed.

The beginning can throw off gamers from seeing the true colors of this game. It almost felt like watching a cartoon with the 'odd' opening cutscene, full of characters you won't be introduced fully to until later, playing right after the setting is introduced. It is unskippable so prepare to watch it and its entirety. Afterwards, feeling skeptical about the game is totally natural. Eventually, this notion is more than compensated with the game's solid gameplay and attention to detail, specifically how the main character, Parin, reacts to people and the environment. As this game is a port from the PSP well over a decade ago, the developers certainly took the time to add in small details that made the game more enjoyable.

The game ramps up difficulty fairly quickly and is proven to be a challenge, especially those who are unprepared. The combat seems to be on point with the game being somewhat forgiving when being damaged, also adding in how invincibility frames plays a role in survivability. However, bare in mind that the controls for some moves are quite sensitive and may activate undesired attacks. Overall, it isn't a terribly difficult game unless you are trying to attempt triple S rank on every stage or playing on Crazy mode, the highest difficulty possible, or perhaps both.

The story is very lighthearted and in many cases child-friendly, but that alone is a big part of the reason why this hidden gem of a game stands out. It is rare to find a good game in the market that isn't even remotely close to having any adultlike values. The voice acting, as amazing as the cast is, can be slightly better though as sometimes there are scenes where the voices of some characters do not match their body language or the current mood of the cutscene.

I recommend playing through this ARPG at least once if you are a fan of RPG-like genres. I would also recommend using a controller if possible as the style of control with keyboard or mouse can be confusing to use. There is simply a ton of replay value and charming RPG elements that is well worth the $9.99 (Guaranteed worth it if bought on sale).

EDIT (Author's Note): This is my first review on a game and did this as this game seems to not be getting enough attention.

-----------------------------------------------

TL;DR - A cute style ARPG that has a few blemishes that shouldn't hinder gamers from enjoying Parin's adventure. This hidden gem game is often very, very overlooked as good.

28824471.review:
Gurumin: A Monstrous Adventure - game that every owner of PSP know. At leats they should, it would be shame if they don't. One of most interesting Playstation Portable games (even tho original released on PC in Japan) are avaible on Steam. Is it worth to get it?

In very short: yes. Why? Because it's very fun. Maybe the story, game style, characters and almost everything feels like a game made for younger gamers. Is Gurumin for kids then? Probably yes, since it's really cute and doesn't include any "bad" elements. That doesn't mean "adults" should avoid it at any costs. It's one of games that makes you feel really relaxed while playing, exploring every levels (and secrets!), trying to reach best possible score and learning more about monster village residents. Gurumin is really well made games and will keep you for many, many hours. I remember playing it for the first time on PSP and I had really much fun unlocking everything and playing on higher difficulty levels. Now I'm doing the same here, on PC. This game strongly reminds me for platformers and such from Playstation 1 era games. Maybe i'm a sucker for cute looking games too.

People sometimes compare Gurumin to Ys or Zelda games. I'm not sure if it's on the same level, but I know one thing - Gurumin: A Monstrous Adventure have its own magical 'something' that's worth playing for. The number of items, unlockables, and overall levels to beat on each difficulty is high, so you won't end your adventure with Parin in few hours.

28383562.review:
...the good:
It's a lot like a classic PS1-era platformer, the graphics are charming and nice, and tharacters are basic, but I like 'em.
The music is very, very good. There's some weird tracks, but Falcom's sound team really knows how to jam.
It's a very straightforward sort of game. Kind of like the later not-bump Ys games, but feels different from them.
Parin's wall-run animation is my favorite thing, I spent like a good twenty minutes when I first started teh game up to just wall-run on everything (as far as I can tell, at no point does she actually need to wall run on things, a normal jump goes just as far if not farther).

...the bad:
The camera has all the same issues that PS1-era games did. Like, all of them.
Determining how far you've moved into the screen is a pain, and if you rotate the camera to the side to cope with it (eg, on a handful of tricky platforming bits), it'll rotate away from that position. It's 30fps locked, and it's an actual native PC game.

...the ugly:
There's not much ugly. I guess it's a bit easy so far?

tl;dr: it's good, play it

28334740.review:
TL;DR Gurumin tries hard. It tries very hard but feels like it lacked a good quality assurance cycle or clear leadership from the creative team and the result is a haphazard mix of good and terrible gameplay. But unfortunately it is more of the latter which makes it not worth purchasing.

And now the full review:

Gurumin wants to be Legend of Zelda so badly that it hurts, but fails to engage the player in all the ways that Nintendo understands. Would it be fair to call it a bad game? Unfortunately since you have to front cash for it, yes it really isn't worth the money and here is why.

The developers have really done a great job on the art-style of the game although the background music varies from great to ear-bleeding, however I will admit that initially it started off very strong. But after about 4 hours of gameplay you suddenly realize how you start to lack any motivation to keep playing. The game is extremely linear although you can choose in which order you want to tackle batches of levels that are unlocked. There is a progression system of a kind with various headgear you unlock and upgrade but in all honesty the only two which you will ever use are the Vampire Disguise hat and the Nightcap since these have the most practical bonuses and overshadow all of the others. You gain new moves but they are just more powerful versions of the same early abilities and there was an attempt to introduce elemental weaknesses with fire/elec/ice but it really causes the combat to become anything but fluid as you pause the game, select the different drillbit and then unpause again. The devs could have simply added hotkeys and it would have really made the game feel much better. There is an unforgivable attempt to extend how long the game is by mirroring levels with some different enemies thrown in. But this also adds to the tedium as you retread the same areas you just completed but in reverse. The 'keep the beat' method of getting critical hits is original but totally unworkable as your attention is focussed on the phantom blob creatures themselves so I don't know why they kept it in the game.

The game quickly runs out of steam and you can tell the developers noticed this as they try to mix things up with platforming sections. Now... 3D platformers are fine but they require some great camera work to ensure that players are able to judge distances and the main character needs to have decent air-control or jumping distance - Gurumin doesn't do any of this and therefore you will often miss landings or plummet to insta-death. Gurumin also does the unforgivable mistake of giving you an ice/snow themed level with precision jumps, sloping edge platforms that Marin will skid off if you don't stay in the middle and slippery surfaces. The level is an exercise in patience as you creep around everywhere and spend much of your time finding the perfect angle for the camera to make that critical jump over insta-death canyons.

There is a plot here.. somewhere... but it really would only appeal to young children (5-7yr olds). However the difficulty of some parts of the game would make the game inaccessible to them. What should be a central driving force to keep the player pushing forwards becomes yet another missing ingredient for a good game. Characters are also 1-dimensional and the developers idea of creating a 'mystery' means they just don't explain why anything is happening or they drizzle out trivial details. That isn't mystery, that's compensating for a shallow story.

Sorry folks but when I reach the point where I want to turn the game off to go do housework because the game is so tedious, you know that there is a problem with it's design.

26416430.review:
Being a cheapskate, and after seeing that the Gurumin was going to be released for the 3DS but at a heftier price, I found out that Gurumin was also available on Steam for less so I made one of the bigger mistakes of 2016 and purchased the game. How was I to know right? After all, a game being remade for the 3DS and gaining quite the amount of attention should be good right? RIGHT? RIGHT? RIGHT?

WRONG.

Choppy graphics, repetitive gameplay, dreadful dialogue and very generic backgrounds. Not to mention the sparse enemy types, wonky hitboxes, poor controls and the dreadful 'BOING' (you all will know what I mean). Just take my word for it when I say that this game is  super generic, and even the different stages are basically reskins of the ones before with changed room placements. 

Equipping the drill with different elements to nothing besides providing a bit more damage against specific enemy kinds without modifying stats or providing skills or abilities. That's quite sad given that the main catch of the game is the drill, and the methods you are supposed to 'improve' your drill basically does not do anything different. Yes, you can buy drill skills, but most of the time you will still end up spamming your normal attack.

Controls are slippery, swimming is horrendous (you have to be at the surface of the water in order to jump out from it and sometimes I was just literally a few pixels away from the surface and wondering why my jump button didn't work) while the fact that the act of swimming itself drains your hitpoints adds to the frustration. Certain areas that requires precision platforming was simply terrible. Add to the fact that there are so many invisible walls and sometimes you're wondering whether the game developers completed programming to a certain point, saw that the game was 'playable' and released the game without programming the remaining parts of the game that were required.

In short, unless there's a Steam sale that puts this below $5, don't get it. And once the game goes for below $5, still don't get it.

04年的老游戏，很早很早以前开的坑，等它上了steam才终于坑完一周目。以目前的眼光来看这款游戏，确实有很多地方做的不好，不过能在steam买这个游戏的，肯定也是一路情怀过来的。

对于新玩家，有以下要注意：

[b] --关于游戏性--[/b]
没得说。玩惯了欧美大作的可能会认为这个游戏很幼稚=.=

[b]--关于画面--[/b]
挺糟糕的，不过毕竟10多年了，支持了1080分辨率已经很不错了。

[b]--关于视角--[/b]
处理的并不好，也是原版遗留的问题。

[b]--关于跳跃--[/b]
除了战斗以外，这个游戏主要把重心放在了跳跃和收集上。对于跳跃是很考验一个玩家的技术和耐心的，因为跳跃判定实在是太糟糕了，非常糟糕。

[b]--关于收集--[/b]
服装、宝箱等等收集是很多的，服装的收集需要多周目解锁。

[b]--关于全成就--[/b]
时间杀。全成就的话大概是需要5或者6周目（没仔细研究），主要是各种收集和全地图S通关。本来想全成就的，可是好多隐藏宝箱找不到，网上的攻略视频也挂了。再加上没什么时间玩游戏了，于是一周目体验下满足情怀了。

8/10

26055423.review:
This game surprised me a lot the moment i decided to play it, mainly because I had no expectations when I played it.

Gameplay
The gameplay is very solid, to the level of normal hack n slash, although the trick/gimmick here is that if you time your attacks to the "beat" you'll deal critical hits, which deal more damage.
The puzzles are extremely easy but it is to be expected of a game that does have childish features. The platforming is average but it does have interesting ways to reach certain targets (like the homming attack that you do when you jump).

Controls
The controls offer different ways to play the game, either only mouse, keyboard and mouse or controller. But I recommend using the controller since it's the intended way of playing it and because you won't get used to the other 2 ways for a while.
The buttons are very responsibe and there's no delay.

Story
The story is extremely simple and easy to follow, you discover a village of monsters and decide to spend some time playing with them, but one day the bad guys from another place start to spread fog in the world and destroy the village, thus your objective is to recontruct the village by getting the objects back to their respective monsters.

Characters
They're childish, but they're enjoyable and there's a good amount of friendly humor in the game.

Soundtrack
As expected from falcom, they deliver in that department and the songs are ones that I would listen from time to time. Not all of them are memorable, but they do offer a good ambientation to the stage.

Overrall
It's a solid game that you'll probably play once (or more if you're a completionist). But it's one that I definetly recommend.

既然之前的被steam吃掉了，而且新评测系统出来了，那就再写一次好了。
记得08年左右第一次玩这款游戏，当时还是因为迷上了空轨，所以把法老空所有的游戏都挖了一遍，什么伊苏啊，双星物语啊等等，也包括这款咕噜小天使，一下子就爱上了这个游戏，记得当时前前后后总共通关了好几次，除了娱乐难度没玩之外，其他的全通了一遍，现在想想也是醉了。简单地说几点这款游戏的优点吧：
1、画风可爱，画面漂亮。虽然精灵的造型其实我不太喜欢，不过女主角帕琳还是蛮可爱的，特别是有些表情很好玩。卡通的画面，虽然比不上现在的游戏那么精美，但是比起很多所谓国产大作来，N年前的游戏，已经很不错了，再加上steam版是算重制版，可以支持1920*1080高清画面，还是很不错的。
2、音乐很好听。游戏中有音乐节奏的元素，在鼓点上打击敌人或者打破罐子等操作，会critical，所以可以的话跟着音乐节奏战斗也是很有必要的。有几个场景的背景乐个人非常喜欢。
3、有换装系统，而且是纸娃娃模式，游戏中可以通过购买或者通关或者拿金币换等方式，获得各种服装以及饰品道具，穿戴后可以在游戏中显示出来，而且很多场景都是实时演算的，过场CG里也可以看到换装后的效果，这点在当时的游戏来讲已经蛮不错了。
4、游戏有丰富的彩蛋，比如电脑系统时间在1月1日新年时，家里的衣柜里会多出一套衣服，公园里爬到铁架最高处可以得到皇冠，还有像蝙蝠运送999块石头可以得到平家头盔，获得的壁纸可以设置为自己电脑桌面壁纸等等，有很多惊喜隐藏在里面。
5、有趣的小谜题。很多关卡前有骷髅，必须要给出正确的答案才可以进门，还有白金奖牌的获得等等，让游戏多了很多趣味性。
6、有二周目以及三周目四周目的奖励，比如不同的服装，还有另外一个可以使用的小女孩，可以让玩家有兴趣玩第二遍第三遍。
7、有很多小游戏，比如跳激光，和蓝猫踢足球等，赢了可以获得相应奖励，也是蛮有意思的。
8、游戏还有就是系统配置要求很低，老电脑都能流畅玩耍，虽然是老游戏，但对XBOX ONE手柄支持的很好
关于缺点，真的很难想得出来，不过说个法老空游戏的一个通病，就是过场动画不能跳过，这点有些让人抓狂，如果玩过一遍之后，也许不太想看剧情了，却不能跳过，挺麻烦的。
就这样，一个充满情怀的游戏，喜欢日式ARPG的朋友可以试试，应该不会让你失望。

22705281.review:
With the Anime Weekend Sale currently going on, I figured I would write up a review of this game.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_JbgaeTarbM&list=PLeIRvBXv8h2PGdYSzAooeQr7lMoC81Z0q&index=1

I acquired this game through a humble bundle and put it in my library, where it was promptly forgotten about. Fast forward a few months when I'm starting up my LP channel on Youtube, and this game's title stuck out to me like a sore thumb. I had no idea what it was going in.

The main character of this game is Parin, a young girl sent to live with her grandfather after her parents go out on an expedition. Tiese Town has no children to speak of and Parin has no one to be friends with.

A few days later, Parin hears a scream and sees a weird little girl cornered by her neighbor's dog. Parin kicks the dog (poor puppy!) and saves the girl. Parin finds out that the girl, Pino, is a monster, and can only be seen by children. Parin is taken to Monster Village by Pino and quickly makes friends with all its inhabitants. The game then goes into a jazzy intro sequence with some awesome music!

GAMEPLAY is very similar in style to the Legend of Zelda: the protagonist moves through dungeons filled with monsters to reach a prize at the end.  I would say it's most similar in style to Ocarina of Time, except all the "waiting" to fight enemies is taken out. The game has a ranking system based on how many monsters you killed in the dungeon, how many treasure chests you opened/how many pots you broke, and how long it took you to complete the dungeon. You unlock new areas by getting furniture from the ends of dungeon and giving it to the inhabitants of Monster Village.

The STORY is also very intriguing; things don't really come to a head until Eggplant Caverns is reached. A lot of things mentioned in passing come together, tying up loose strings that you thought didn't matter.

The GRAPHICS are kind of cartoony, which gives it a unique and charming look; this game was originally released in 2004, and brought to Steam in 2015. The graphics held up really well!

The MUSIC for this game is super jazzy, in a good way! All of the tracks are pleasant to listen to, and very memorable. I would say that it's almost on the same level of Jet Set Radio's soundtrack. (here's a link to my favorite song from the Gurumin OST:) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OGmoyZNfnlQ

All in all, Gurumin is a very charming game and definitely one that should be part of your library. If you want to get an idea of what gameplay is like, I've linked the first episode of my LP at the top of this review. :)

22623233.review:
Basically, it's low rent Ys: Oath in Felghana/origin with a more lighthearted story.  There's a lot of love put into this game and there's much to like, but conversely this was likely a B-team or frugal project.

The soundtrack as expected of a falcom game from the era is great (with the exception of one minigame track).  Visuals and story are pretty basic but serviceable.

Although combat and the main mechanics/item management are additive and fun, in general the loose design, mediocre platforming control/camera and recycled levels are the game's main weakness.  You won't see much of it if you simply race to the end, but if you shoot to do all the levels pretty much everything's used twice- there's really more music than there are unique stages.  Still, the game's got decent replay value given how tricky it is to get everything.  It also has some nice little puzzles and minigames thrown into the mix to vary things up a smidge.

In summation, the game's value is decent for its cost, but unless the setting really appeals to you or you want something a little easier I'd play the Ys games that are on Steam first.

22562125.review:
This game is absolutely sweet. It's pretty much a rated E for everyone, obviously a kids game, but I'm sure you'll enjoy the charm of this game regardless of age.
It reminds me a bit of those PS1 action platformers like crash bandicoot and spyro and such. Probably because of the graphics quality and style.

While it looks a bit low poly, the graphics is good enough for what it does, and the style makes up for it. It all look pretty cute.
The quality on sound effects and music is quite good.

The action platforming is also quite nice, not too easy, and certainly not too diffcult. 
The bosses in the game pack quite a punch, but by the first boss you'll probably have figured out how to dodge those.

All 'n all, a great game for anyone that loves 3d action platformers.

22333295.review:
Esse jogo foi originalmente lançado pra PC na Ásia em 2004 pela Nihon Falcon e só chegou ao ocidente em sua versão de psp em 2007. Só no ano passado que o jogo chegou pra PC totalmente dublado e traduzido pra inglês, em uma dublagem decente mas que poderia ser melhor. 
Nesse jogo você acompanha a vida de uma menina chamada Parin que acabou de se mudar pra Tiese Town(para morar com o avô, pelos pais estarem viajando), uma cidade mineradora. Assim que ela chega lá encontra uma garota sendo atacada por um cachorro, ela a salva e ela descobre que só ela pode vê-la. Essa garota é um monstro que apenas crianças podem ver. A garota monstro a leva ao seu vilarejo, e lá Parin ao melhor estilo rei arthur puxa uma broca de uma pedra e descobre ser a escolhida que irá salvar o mundo dos monstros e dos humanos de Tokaron, um dragão boladão que está aprisionado e irá destruir o mundo se escapar.
Remetendo os gráficos de um jogo de dreamcast e com uma estrutura que lembra um jogo de ps1 ou nintendo 64, você já percebe que ele é um jogo lançado fora de sua época. Se ele tivesse sido lançado pra ps1 na época(com os gráficos piorados claro) seria um dos meus jogos favoritos.
O jogo tem um mapa mundi ao estilo de Super Mario World aonde você pode acessar as fases.O replay é gigantesco apesar do jogo ter apenas entre 15 e 40 horas, porque é possível gastar horas tentando conseguir ranks altos nas fases ou mesmo caçando os colecionáveis, farmando lixo ou dinheiro, explorando os minigames, conversando com os npcs, melhorando os inúmeros chapéus(que vão do level 1 ao 5) ele é muito completo. O jogo tem um problema técnico um pouco chato porque se você ativar o v sync o jogo fica com a imagem normal mas tem um delay tem meio segundo entre o pressionar do botão e a ação da personagem, o que atrapalha principalmente nas fases da montanha que tem muita plataforma pequena, e nos minigames dos carrinhos de mineiro. A solução é desligar o v sync, que resolve o problema do controle mas aí o jogo fica com screen tearing nos gráficos, um problema conhecido pros jogadores de pc. 
O jogo peca porque ele não tem opção pra dublagem em japonês, alguns poucos textos no jogo(cerca de 3) estão em japonês; essa versão parece ser um update da versão em hd do Gurumin original e não da versão de 2007 de psp que tinha a opção de dublagem em japonês e algumas roupas extras, mas que pra compensar, tinha os gráficos piorados.

O mundo é dividido em 5 areas basicamente: montanhas, floresta, ruinas, cavernas e a última caverna que é a última area do jogo, além de uma area secreta com um chefe extra.  Cada uma dessas areas tem cerca de 3 a 6 fases, além de algumas terem areas neutras que servem pra conversar com npcs do jogo, bosses que você derrotou, procurar items escondidos ou fazer minigames que são: futebol, um jogo pra bater em marmotas, um jogo de destruir pedras entre outros. Ao terminar as fases você pega, no final da mesma, um móvel ou objeto que pertence a um monstro(da vila dos montros), e isso o deixa mais feliz, e faz liberar uma fase nova, já que todas as fases estão bloqueadas porque os monstros estão tristes pela sua casa estar destruida e por terem perdido todos os seus objetos... é meio idiota, mas é assim que funciona. Em dado um momento existem quests extras com os monstros, que fazem liberar papéis de paredes que você ativa na mesa do quarto de parin. Ao mudar o papel de parede dentro do jogo, o seu desktop realmente fica com outro papel de parede, algo no mínimo curioso.
Apesar da temática infantil, tem alguma coisa que me prendeu nesse jogo, o combate é excelente, a trilha é boa, os personagens são simpáticos, mesmo já sabendo desde o começo o grande plot twist do jogo, isso não me incomodou, e continuei achando ele um jogo muito gostoso de jogar. Ele virou pra mim durante o tempo que estava farmando lixo pra melhorar os chapéus, um jogo excelente de se jogar ouvindo podcasts. 
As armas tem 3 elementais nela: fogo, gelo e eletricidade, cada um com uma finalidade e os chapéus tem cada um, uma função diferente: o chapéu do vampiro por exemplo recupera a vida ao acertar golpes críticos nos inimigos, o óculos serve pra nadar, a mascara de gás pra se proteger de veneno e por aí vai. Esses chapéus podem ser upados em 5 níveis, que pra serem upados precisam de 10, 50, 250 e 999 pedaços de lixo pra serem upados, mas tem um segredo muito bom que é usar uma coroa de rainha e upa-la até o level 5 pra conseguir descontos de até 50% nas lojas. 
O jogo tem um problema bem grave com a camera dele já que não é possível move-la pra cima e pra baixo, infelizmente, o que atrapalha em fases que dependem de plataforma, além de ela ser lenta pra virar, com o tempo eu acabei me acostumando.
O final(o jogo tem 2 finais, eu peguei o bom) dele me decepcionou um pouco, entra em contraste com o resto do jogo, e criou um clima ruim que não precisava ter existido na minha opinião, apesar dele ter sido coerente. 
Se você gosta de jogos com gráficos em cell-shading, com estilo retrô, e é fã dos jogos antigos estilo megaman legends, Brave Fencer Mushashi ou mesmo um zelda, vale a pena dar uma conferida. Uma pérola subestimada e desconhecida.

22107668.review:
Hab den Storymode durch und wie immer steht ganz unten alles nochmal zusammengefasst

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Das Spiel macht von der Aufmachung her zwar den Eindruck eines "Childs-Only-Titels" wird aber ab Mitte zum Ende hin langsam aber sicher recht kniffelig, da die Hüpfpassagen Reaktionsvermögen und Koordination verlangen.
Man steuert das Mädchen "Parin" (Name änderbar) durch kunter bunte Dungeons, die mit allerlei Puzzeln und Hüpfpassagen aufwarten sowie zahlreichen Gegnern, die sich unterschiedlicher Mittel bedienen wie Kanonen oder Bomben. Insgesammt verlangte mir als Actionadventureneuling das Spiel einiges ab. Vorallem die Bossgegner, die bei Bedarf wiederholt werden können, finde ich insgesammt wirklich gut umgesetzt. 

Im Verlauf des Spiels findet man unterschiedlichste Items, die man für den Kampf oder allgemein um in den levels weiter zu kommen nutzen kann wie zum Beipsiel eine Taucherbrille, die einen davor bewahrt im Wasser Schaden zu nehmen.
Oder einem Hut, der offensive wie deffensive Fähigkeiten der Protagonistin stärkt und alle kann man verstärken, deswegen vermutlich der RPG-Tag, denn außer einer temporären Steigerung der Kraft der eigenen Waffe durch krittische Treffer (die man nur durch gutes Timing erzielt) gibt es an dem Spiel insgesammt nix groß RPG-mäßiges.

Insgesammt erinnert das Gameplay von Gurumin eher an ein Actionadventure mit Plattformeranleihen als an ein RPG, weshalb ich es für fraglich halte, ob es legitim ist, das als RPG zu bezeichnen. Ein Plattformer-Tag halte ich da für sinnvoller.

[b]Soundtrack[/b]
Der Soundtrack ist meiner Meinung nach durchgehend gut umgesetzt und jeder Boss hat ein eigenes Bosstheme (das was im Hintergrund gespielt wird, während man den Boss bekämpft)

[b]Steuerung[/b]
Ich habe das Spiel mit Maus und Tastatur gespielt, weil das Spiel meinen Controler nicht erkannt hat, weshalb ich es schätze ich ein wenig schwerer hatte, allerdings war es insgesammt ganz gängig, außer dass ich manche Spezialattacken, die für eine effektive Anwendung genaues Handling erfordern, nicht wirklich sinnbringend in Kämpfen nutzen konnte.

[b]Zusammenfassung[/b]
Pro
[list]
    [*]abwechslungsreiches Gameplay
    [*]vorallem für Archivementhunter interessant, da man für Levels unterschiedlich bewertet wird
    [*]guter Soundtrack
    [*]relativ frustfrei gestaltet und daher für jüngere und ältere interessant
    [*]Humor (Geschmackssache)
[/list]
Contra
[list]
    [*]Steuerung für Maus und Tastatur nur bedingt editierbar
    [*]Eher für Controler ausgelegt und mit Maus und Tastatur mitunter etwas problematisch
[/list]

[b]Fazit[/b]
Gurumin ist ein Geheimtipp für Actionadventurefreunde, die auch Plattformer mögen

22102475.review:
Ganz nett, hält aber keinen Vergleich zu alten Klassikern stand

Wenn ein Spiel mit Titeln wie Ys und Zelda gleichgesetzt wird, schürt das freilich Erwartungen, die dann in den meisten Fällen nicht erfüllt werden. So auch in Gurumin: A Monstrous Adventure, welches mit seiner mittelmäßigen, kunterbunten Grafik und kitschigen Präsentation ohnehin eher auf Kinder zurechtgeschnitten wurde. Dementsprechend fallen auch einige Gameplay-Inhalte oberflächlicher aus, als sie sein sollten. Zumindest die Rätsel und das Leveldesign der strunzlinearen Dungeons sorgen für gepflegte Langeweile und haben abgesehen von einer gewissen Grundbasis nicht viel mit Zelda gemein. Den Kämpfen fehlt hingegen die herrliche Simplizität und Schnelligkeit eines Ys-Titels.
Ältere Semester werden sich mit Gurumin also eher langweilen, was jetzt nicht bedeutet, dass das Spiel schlecht wäre. Gurumin wird zwar niemanden zu Jubelrufen hinreißen, verbreitet aber durchaus einen gewissen Charme der einem zumindest für den Großteil des ersten Spieldurchlaufs bei der Stange hält. Bevor ich nun zum Ende komme noch mal die klare Ansage, dass ein Controller bei diesem Spiel absolute Pflicht ist! Mit Maus und Tastatur ist Gurumin ungenießbar und somit von vorneherein keine Überlegung wert.


Pro und Kontra:

Pro:
- netter Mix aus Action-RPG, Action-Adventure und 3D Jump'n'Run
- charmante Charaktere
- bietet viele freischaltbare Extras und Schwierigkeitsgrade 

Neutral:
- kinderfreundliche, teils sehr kitschige Präsentation
- Spezialangriffe erfordern zu viel Fingerakrobatik

Kontra:
- Controller-Pflicht da Maus- und Tastatur-Steuerung unzumutbar ausfällt
- generell mangelhafte Kamerasteuerung
- Rätsel- und Dungeondesign sind zu oberflächlich
- Grafik wirkt selbst für ein 2004er PC-Spiel nicht überzeugend

22019212.review:
Falcom made Ys, this must be like a little relaxing, more childlike Ys game right?  Probably some good music, decently fun, something I can relax to with a good atmosphere harkening back to the olden days of something like a PS1 or N64 game, right?

No.  The game scores you on something so stupid as destroying jars, which is boring, and a terrible mechanic.  Who thought destroying jars was a central mechanic?  Finding secrets, sure, something to entice exploration, but I'll be damned if I'm going to stop to poke every jar with my drill.

That's just a game killer right there, and that's not even mentioning the fact that the PC controls are abysmal.  I tried to get a gamepad set up, a DS4, that I use for everything using DS4 Windows.  It's never failed me yet, and I love it.  With this game, however, it repeatedly sets to Button 2 every time I go to set the bindings.  Only this one.  This forces me to use a clunky movement style that makes jumps nearly impossible.  Don't forget, you don't jump until you RELEASE the jump button, and the jumping sound will spam repeatedly until you do.

It's also a bore to start up.  Takes a long while to even start playing, and you're just forced to watch cutscenes with terrible voice acting, a Saturday morning cartoon intro with a bunch of crap you don't actually understand, and some stupid song that rivals Street Fighter 4's vanilla theme (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cYK_4zut03U) in how awful it is.

Skip it/10

20841132.review:
I want to start off saying this isn't a bad game. The reason why I leave this game a negative review is because the description on the game's page is misleading. The game advertises itself as have 35+ hours of gameplay; however, this is incorrect. On average, it takes maybe 11 hours to beat the game. I looked up the game on the HowLongtoBeat website and it is listed as 9-11 hours and 17 hours for completionists, meaning that even for people who want to experience all of the content in the game, it only takes them 17 hours on average, which is half the amount of time that the game makers advertise. One of the reasons I originally purchased this game was because I believed I'd be getting a decent game length out of it, and I didn't. I don't have anything against shorter games, but it was a game I had been expecting to put more time into because of this advertisement. 

I will go over the game's pros and cons now.

Pros:
-Decent platforming game with unique levels
-Good for people who like to collect items or beat their own high scores/times
-Cute character designs
-Catchy music
-Wearing items changes the costume on the character
-Runs well even on non-gaming pcs and laptops

Cons:
-Game can be beaten in 9-17 hours on average (not as advertised 35+)
-Characters are not fleshed out enough
-Unlocking areas or progressing the story is sometimes extremely obscure without a guide
-There is an adult character that tries to go on dates with the little girls in the game and it is passed off like a silly joke. This part particularly irked me because the game is otherwise appropriate for kids to play and yet it normalizes a grown adult trying to pursue romantic relationships with prepubescent girls. This is another reason why I choose not to recommend the game, but the main reason is the false advertisement.

20765879.review:
This is without a doubt one of the best action-adventure games I've ever played. It's also the most Dreamcast-feeling game I've ever played, and I had Sonic Adventure on an actual Dreamcast.

The graphics are beautiful and hit the style they were aiming for perfectly. The combat is fluid, deceptively deep and not as repetative of most games of its genre. The humor is on point, the mini-games are varied and enjoyable, there's plenty of world-interaction and always chance NPCs will have something new to say. Plenty of replayability with its mission rankings, from C to S+++, and so full of childish joy that you won't want to put the controller down.

Playing this game will feel like the first time you tried Mario 64 or Banjo. Do not miss out!

通关撒花：咕噜小天使，未开启二周目的不完全结局。特别喜欢本作的玩家，在决战最终BOSS之前需要开启并完成其他支线，这样才能在打完破坏龙之后存档并开启二周目。顺便提下，这是一个一开始没朋友的萌萝莉为怪物朋友们两肋插刀的故事。

可收集金钱、徽章和怪物装备残渣，用于在小镇里各NPC处换取或是升级饰品。场景里觉得突兀的东西都可以用蓄力击来进行破坏并得到金钱，墙上裂缝也是一样。换上不同的钻头部件可以开启不同的机关，雷、火、冰属性部件为开机关所必需。

各迷宫入口处的骷髅守卫基本都可用金币进行贿赂得到提示或者直接放行，价格也不一样。有一处骷髅守卫对金钱不感兴趣，他的兴趣是：萌萝莉。此处需要把系统时间改成1月1日，然后在爷爷家楼上的衣柜里找到一身和服，换上之后再去找骷髅守卫，他会被萌到不分东南西北然后直接放行。

【特别提醒：密码输入注意大小写。】

关于各种饰品：在老爷爷那里用金牌换到的小猴帽子可以增加捡到的金钱数量，攒够金牌可以换一个。另外还有防护陷阱伤害、水下伤害等等不同作用的饰品，可以用金钱购买。都很可爱啊，给萌萝莉换装然后截图什么的最棒了。小镇里每个NPC都是有用的，分别对话就知道他们的作用了。

感觉萌萝莉偶尔会有些有勇无谋，不过很可爱就不要在意这些细节了，萌即是正义。

Pros:
It's a cute game with quite a bit of content especially if you're a completionist I've read that you need to beat all difficulties to unlock a new character. Sadly, I am not a completionist and couldn't even be bothered to get S on all the maps. The soundtrack has some interesting songs. There are 4 or so minigames. All in all it's a good game.

Cons:
Some soundtracks you hear too much and really get annoying. The map ranking is determined by if you killed all the monsters and broke all the jars so 60% of the time you're just breaking jars. The combat gets very stale (Charge attack to knock off armor then finish with normal attacks) swap goggles for swimming and gas mask for mushrooms but then spend most of your time with vampire hat for free heals (I couldn't be bothered to get the better ones than vamp.) I'd probably suggest getting native voices too since english ones aren't that great. Story is spread waaaaaay too thin, most of the time you just run maps to get the dark mist to go away, feels really unheroic to be collecting missing furnature for 80% of the game.

Incredible game. Reminds me of Legend of Zelda. The story is really cute; you're a lonely child in a town with no other children who eventually discovers a monster who you save from a dog. [b]GURUMIN[/b] is an old-school style game that is reminiscent of a much simpler time. by today's standards, it is admittedly flawed and full of imperfections. but it's got a LOT of heart. despite any of the game's shortcomings, its nostalgic appeal and charming personality are guaranteed to win you over unless you basically have no soul.

[h1]PROS[/h1]
-whimsical action/adventure rpg with lovable characters
-provides a decent challenge despite its cute appearance
-plenty of unlockable content to keep you busy
-soundtrack has some catchy tunes ♥
-the town miner is a pedophile but nobody minds

[h1]CONS[/h1]
-combat lacks variety and gets a little repetitive, though puzzles and minigames do help to break up the pace
-animations are hard-locked at 30fps

overall this game is an underrated gem and a must-play for fans of the low-poly (PS1/N64) era of gaming! give it a try and you will feel like a kid again. i promise.

19346471.review:
Portage d'un jeu PSP ou pas, Gurumin reste un action-RPG objectivement très moche ("graphics" pas "stunning" du tout) et d'une banalité abyssale. Les dialogues sont totalement inintéressants, le scénario tient sur un post-it (les méchants ils cassent le village des gentils) et le système de combat se résume à appuyer en rythme sur un bouton (en gros).

Pour le reste, vous vous déplacez sur une carte (moche) pour prendre part à des missions qui consistent à nettoyer des niveaux ou tuer des boss pour ensuite livrer des objets en ville. Mais là où le jeu se révèle réellement passionnant, c'est quand il faut pousser des caisses sur des interrupteurs et tirer des leviers pour ouvrir des portes.

Nan franchement, je veux bien casser des pots remplis de pièces, me battre avec une foreuse enflammée, mettre des chapeaux en guise d'équipement ou me taper des persos au look discutable (héroïne en tête) mais les caisses et les leviers, c'est trop pour moi.

19326312.review:
This game harkens back to the days of old (when I say old, I mean like 10 years ago). Gurumin looks, feels, and sounds like a PS2 era platformer ( it might even smell and taste like one too!). Now if you're looking for some nostalgia, this is a game for you. While the graphics are not top of the line, the cel shaded style more than makes up for it. There are quite a few low res textures, but it's easy to ignore. The gameplay itself is pretty fun. You go around crawling through several levels beating up enemies on the way. It's similar to many of the PS2 era platforming games like Crash Bandicoot, Spyro, Jak and Dexter, etc. 

But there are some things to take not of. First of all, the first 20 minutes or so are confusing. The intro is pretty horrendous, in that it feels as if it cut out a large part of the story (you'll see what I mean). Speaking of story, it's definitely no tell tale games. It's pretty generic, but it does the job. 
The voice acting is... extremely underwhelming. The character (Parin) will often be seen flailing her arms, yet the voice actor is merely mumbling. Also, the game is capped at 30 fps for some reason. Not a game breaker by any means, but it's something to note.

Bon pour avoir testé et approuvé ce jeu voila les raisons...

De 1, l'ambiance, bien que bon enfant, ne demontre pas moins un succulent melange de decors qui ne saurait rappeler Skies Of Arcadia pour els nostalgiques. On incarne une petite rousse, qui aide des monstres de son plein gré. Donc une petite rousse de secours en gros. Blague a part, le jeu est bouré d'humour. quoiqu'un peu space. notemment Cylinder qui fera des avance....oui oui, un adulte qui fais des avances a un enfant.... allez tous avec moi, et on chante "pédophiiiile d'ici, pédophillle tres loiiiiin, pedophile d'iciiii avec tes sales maniiiiies"

Bon maintenant, on va faire dans la critique objective; le jeu est sympatoche, la prise en main assez facile, on enchaine les combos assez aisement, et la camera n'est pas chiante. Les monstres sont, pour le peu que j'ai joué, assez coloré et varié. On accede a differentes attaques via un processus de leveling assez long mais pas trop, donc qui ne degoute pas de jouer pour upgrader. L'histoire est un peu vue et revue. Vous etes la seule a pouvoir aider les gens, vous etes forcemment l'elue, et bien entendue, vous etes la seule personne equipé d'un baton "drill" style sextoy plug-anal pour film de marc dorcel qui pûisse vaincre les mechants. Quelle chance. Le pedophile du coin vous aidera a upgrader votre arme en vous permettant moyenant argent d'etoffer votre gamme de coups. (et pour tout vous dire, il voulait un rdv galant avec vous en echange de prime abords....paye ta prostitution+chantage) et un autre marchand vous proposera de lui acheter des accesoires, permettant a chacun de limiter certains degats, puis aussi de les upgrader via des objets que les monstres ont parfois d'equipé. ça evite de mettre la main a la bourse (oui le jeu de mots malsains va avec) mais cependant, comme il en faut un sacré paquet, vous farmez aussi doublement... et ouais)

Quoiqu'il en soit, le jeu est attrayant, et on se verra sans probleme jouer quelques bonnes heures dessus sans broncher.

Maintenant, quelques petits trucs speciaux, la gamine se verra en mode transformation style sailor moon quand elle monte sur une stele de soin (en gros elle est nue entourée d'un halo de lumiere, se soignera et recup ses vetement aussitot.... decidement...) et y a un monstre Français (ouais ouais, jvous le jure) qui s'apelle......PIerre commes les trois quarts des jeux jap incluant un français.... vous aurez alors le plaisir de voir chez francophones, quelques mots de dans la langue de Hugo et d'entendre des mots aussi de ce monstre. A bon entendeur, et autres pedo, bon jeu !

19253975.review:
This is the third time i buy and play this game, and it's still worth it.

This game is a charming little action adventure from Falcom, with a light story, some really goofy characters and a nice colorful artstyle.
Most of the gameplay is simple but addicting, it's a nice little fighting system with some basic combo's, and some expandable or upgradable attacks. There are about 25 levels and some bosses to complete plus some minigames, and if you want to collect all outfits, upgrade all items, and get S+ ratings on every level, there's plenty of playing time.

Aside from that, absolutely love this game!

19249921.review:
This is a surprisingly fun game. The characters seem well developed, and are voiced, combat is fun... a nicely designed game. And I expect nothing else from Falcom.

Combat seems fairly simplistic so far, I expect more complicated moves to pull off will be added later on. Simplistic is not a bad thing though. The combat is enjoyable, easy to pick up, and has a couple interesting mechanics; like the critical hit timing bar. The enemies also seem balanced and combat is not drawn out to the point that I don't want to play. *cough X-Blades cough*

All the characters are voiced, although not all the text is voiced. I... am of mixed opinions on the voice acting. Some of it is good, but a good chunk of it seems like the voice does not fit the character (main character for example has the voice that does not match the little kid she is supposed to be) or has no emotion (one character talking about how his village got destroyed but is said in the exact same tone as when he's asking you to come to his village). The big thing is that all the characters have their own personality and none are just cut and paste throw away characters. Bonus points for the main characters grandpa as he actually does seem senile. 

Music is not bad, it matches what you are doing, and the critical hit timing bar being tied to the music is an interesting, and unique touch. I honestly can not remember any that I've heard off the top of my head, but that just means it was neither cringe worthy bad or super memoriable. 

The controls feel clunky if you use the default ones. I manually inverted the horizontal camera movement and moved around all the controls to my liking. But it DOES allow you to change them! Far too many games make it so you can't remap the controls, so if they suck you are out of luck. It took me all of 5 minutes to get them to my liking and didn't have a single issue with them afterwards. My only complaint is the spot to remap them is on the config screen before the game actually starts up and not in game itself, so you have to exit, change, then restart to see if they're to your liking. But... you can change them, so I'll let that slide.

Oh, game does not auto-save. But you can save whenever you want. So save fairly often.

Overall, this is a run and enjoyable game that I am looking forward to playing more of. And this review will be updated with any changes of opinion I have towards it.

19206790.review:
[b]TL;DR[/b]: Don't be fooled by first impressions. Gurumin gets better a couple of hours in, and is very nostalgic of N64 and PS1 era games, so a great one for sitting on the couch and devoting a weekend or more to!

[b]NOTE:[/b] If you don't like the English voices there's a zip of the Japanese voices here: https://steamcommunity.com/app/322290/discussions/0/611701999538422445/  The English main character is probably better than the Japanese, but both suffer from lack of enthusiasm compared to the animation.

[b]REVIEW:[/b]
This game does not present itself well in the beginning. The intro music is certainly an interesting choice in much the same way the unskippable movie it accompanies is - it reminds me of a Saturday morning cartoon's attempt to appeal to "the youth", so it's just a bit cheesy. That sets the tone for the first little while of the game really, you just can't help but treat it with a skeptical:[i]"am I actually going to enjoy this...?"[/i] after the intro. It's as though Gurumin saved all of its A-Game material for later, then realised it still had to actually [i][b]start[/b][/i] somehow, so just threw in a montage of characters you don't know, to music that you weren't prepared for, then pretended it couldn't hear you when you told it to stop.

That feeling dissipated over the next hour or so though as the game began to remember that it actually isn't bad [i](or maybe my hangover just eased...)[/i]. The music gradually gets better throughout the game, comprising hints of RPGs from bygone eras intermingled with... well, bits of everything really! In fact some of the tracks are downright awesome despite being anything but the norm for this genre! The writing style begins to feel more familiar as it goes on, and for the most part delivers on the "sensible chuckle" humour; Though I do take issue with the more liberal translations, like adding [i]"You stink!"[/i] where the original Japanese character just noisily pratfalled.

The combat is a mixed bag of genuine challenge [i](read: oh-god-where-did-my-health-go)[/i] as well as confusion [i](like hitting fish underwater)[/i]. To keep it quick; it gets better as it goes on, and you get used to the lack of feedback compared to more mordern games. This could have been better handled, but it's easily forgiveable considering this was a [strike]PSP[/strike] [i][b](it was in fact released on PC in 2004 as noted by Genki in the comments. Thanks!)[/b][/i] title originally released in 2004, and it plays well enough to be mastered if you're bothered enough to pay attention to the timing. You gain more abilities, weapon elements and upgrades as you go, all of which are up to you, so there's a decent feeling of agency here. There's even a special "Beginner Mode" which in addition to reduced damage and penalities, also stops ice from being slippery, which is just a really thoughtful feature! Gurumin could be great for all ages and player skills as a result, though younger kids might still need some help with the puzzles.

There's also keyboard and mouse support which can be remapped before playing, and adding that to the high resolution capability makes this an example of a port done right!

[b]The big of the smalls is this:[/b] Despite initial apprehension and a couple of hours of admitted "hrm...", something kept calling me back to the game and I actually had a lot of fun! Maybe it's just that it reminds me of games from the Nintendo 64 or original Playstion, like Croc or Mario 64 or even Ocarina of Time, but I just HAD to play this game sitting on my couch in front of my TV. And... that's all I've done pretty much for 2 days straight now! And hopefully many more to come! This is a stupidly cute, amazingly solid, retro-console styled game through-and-through. So make use of the Steam streaming function if you can, and play it on the couch on the biggest TV you can find!

Additional: Parin's animations are adorable.

18404475.review:
TL;DR I got the game for free and I feel robbed, it's buggy and Mastiff should be ashamed.

Thoughts:
Great game, I love Falcom and their games, but Mastiff's effort in the publishing of Gurumin is non-existent.
The game does have a few faults by default, one being the overly sensitive input for performing special moves (You'll sometimes do spin attacks by turning only a half circle before attacking). People who use controllers (myself included) may also find the analogue input to be overly sensitive as well, which just comes down to needing to adjust the deadzone of your controller.

Now for the things that Mastiff did wrong:
As you get past the halfway point you'll soon notice several lines of dialogue being unacceptably incomplete.

A couple of steam achievements do not unlock properly and requires you to beat the final boss and watch the whole ending TWICE per difficulty to unlock both, that is if you actually made a save before a certain point in the game, otherwise you'll have to replay the whole game to unlock the other achievement.

The unlockable Item List does not update properly and is showing a majority of blanks despite having beaten the game to 100% twice.

The PSP version (Also published by Mastiff) has content which this version does not, including:
At least 5 extra costumes.
Original Japanese voice line option (Available on the PC version through manually downloading and overwriting audio files with original Jap audio, search Steam threads if you're interested)
Skippable cutscenes.


Conclusion:
I would've recommended this game outright simply because it's another great Falcom game, but this version is an example of publishing done wrong, Mastiff has put in minimal effort to properly bring a good product to Steam.
If this had been published by XSEED we would've had a version of the game with full uncensored content for sure and without any bugs.

18377415.review:
REALLY enjoyed this on the PSP (although I never made it past Happy mode as I wanted to fully complete the game), if you are deciding whether or not you want to own this, then here is a simplified checklist that may make this game more appealing to you.

-A game with a cute, anime artstyle and animation, with a charming and captivating cast of characters!

-That kind of game where you'd think the English dub would be atrocious, when it isn't! It features an all-star voice cast featuring the voice talents of actors you may have heard from before! (ex. Pierre and Doug are voiced by Robin Atkin Downes, aka The Medic and Dee Bradley Baker, most known for voicing many Spongebob characters is in this too!)

-A storyline that at times can be serious, but most of the time doesn't take itself seriously and has many light-hearted elements.

-An absolutely awesome and always upbeat and rocking soundtrack!

-Simple and intuitive controls (not to mention fluid)

-Has RPG elements but for those who are new to games with RPG elements, this game simplifies them, saving you the stress of understanding them.

-A ultra-simple equip mechanic, just put on a different piece of headgear on the fly to use its attributes to turn the tide in battle! (PLUS headgear can be further upgraded, gaining new perks and even strengthening its current attributes!)

-LOTS of collectibles and extras, perfect for the gamers who like to collect everything and for completionists!

-This game may have linear progression, but 100% of the time it encourages players to explore the areas (hidden areas, breakable walls) and are rewarded for their curiosity for going out of the beaten path.

-A unique lineup of enemies that have the players think of which strategies and/or weaknesses to use on them.

-Formidable boss battles that have patterns players must adapt to (it's more fun to experiment methods of defeating the bosses everytime in newer, faster, and more efficient ways!)

-5 Difficulty levels to challenge the player (it's okay for newcomers to choose the Beginner difficulty, but once they get the hang of the game, they are free to tackle the higher difficulties and are awarded new items for clearing them, there's even a hidden playable character when special conditions are met!)

And that should cover all the details about this game and if you should get it (I mean need I say more?). This game gets my highest recommendation and I cannot recommend this game enough.

18248387.review: Gurumin ist ein liebenswertes und gut gemachtes Action-RPG, das sichtlich von den älteren Zelda Titeln inspiriert wurde. Zwar ist die Grafik für heutige Verhältnisse unterdurchschnittlich, aber Modelle und Welt sind nett gemacht und erledigen ihren Job. Wie bei den älteren Zelda Titeln ist die Grafik Anime-typisch und kindlich gehalten. Die Musik erinnert an die alten Klassiker der Computerspielgeschichte - dieses typische Soundprozessor-Gedudel. Auch lustig: Wer im Takt auf die Monster haut, landet kritische Treffer. Die Dungeons sind gut aufgebaut und kommen durchaus an die großen Vorbilder heran. Die Geschichte ist unterhaltsam, die Charaktere liebenswert, Rätsel und Schwierigkeitsgrad einfach bis fair. Das Spiel bleibt durchwegs kindgerecht. Nervig: Für den XBox Controller werden nicht die richtigen Buttons angezeigt, z.B. wenn man "Z" drücken soll, ist XBox "A" gemeint. Mit ein wenig Probieren kommt man aber trotzdem leicht zurecht. Leider ist die Steuerung nicht 100% per Controller möglich, ab und zu (selten) braucht man eine Tastatur. Das sind so die gewissen kleinen Schwächen. Mit gegenwärtig 10 Euro ist auch der Normalpreis in Ordnung.

18234042.review:
This game is super cute. I got it for half price but it's cheap enough anyway. It reminds me in some ways of the old Ape Escape games, and many 3D rpgs in fact. The music and sounds are adorable, albeit slightly annoying after a while, and the monsters are vibrant and loveable too.

The game works with a system of levels, each of which will earn you a grade based on how well you do, much like can be seen in Sonic Adventure. You can replay rounds to better your score and earn more valuable medals, which in turn can be traded for new gear. With each stage completed, new stages are gradually unlocked.

All in all the game is rather simplistic and your inventory space is somewhat lacking, but it's just the kind of typical action game to entertain you for a few hours at a time. Different moves, abilities and specialist gear offer a small amount of versitility but if you're happy just whacking baddies with a giant drill then you're pretty much set for a childish but excellent adventure.

You can wear hats to gain special effects and the music is nice and you can hit enemies to the rhythm of the BGM to deal critical hits. It's pretty good.

18204184.review:
引用琪琪子的評論:
娱乐通出的中文版早在几年前就通关了两遍，前一阵子发现绿光上有投票免费领key的投票，就抱着+1的心态投了yes。当时以为这只是个将文本翻成英文的版本而已，没想到上个月看介绍视频的时候发现配音也换成了英文，尤其是里边帕琳的配音真是让我萌得不行，心态也一下子从+1变成了非常期待。今天游戏一放出来就赶紧下载下来试玩了一会，果然英文配音质量非常棒，尤其是帕琳那带点哑的萝莉音和皮诺的甜萝莉音，真是超萌啊，光是冲这一点就绝对值得再通关一遍。

除了配音以外，再说点和记忆中的中文版不太一样的地方。英文版一开始就开启了所有难度，我记得中文版原来是锁住一些难度的。进入游戏后，一开始就可以在衣柜处换上所有服装（我选择的是最简单的难度，其他难度开没开启不清楚），这真的是一个很方便的设定，原来的中文版想要收集全服装并不是一件轻松的事，而且一出来就可以使用泳装也大大降低了游戏难度。英文版在这方面做得确实比较体贴人。

虽然我的这份游戏是免费领的，但是优秀的英文配音和一些改良的设计还是值得喜欢这个游戏的老玩家+1收藏的。对于没有玩过游戏的新玩家来说，游戏本身的素质也绝对对得起它的价格。虽然它是一个2004年的游戏，但是它的趣味性并不输于现在的游戏。

最后说一点题外的，不知道是因为轨迹是近藤亲儿子还是什么别的原因，falcom这几年的游戏质量是越做越烂，除了没完没了的轨迹就是没完没了的轨迹，终于在闪轨这一代（1+2）来了次爆发，白开水（闪轨1）/屎（闪轨2）一样的剧情+乏味到极点的游戏流程几乎把牌子都砸了。这也是难免的事，当一个游戏公司不断在重复过去赚回忆钱而不思进取的时候，就离失败不远了，国内的几把逗比剑就是这么完蛋的，虽然falcom水平比国内几个逗比厂商水平高些不至于死掉，但轨迹系列估计也就这么烂尾了。今天重新玩到这个falcom在2004年发售的游戏，还是能感受到十足的趣味，再联想前一阵子刷逗比闪轨二周目，连一点趣味都感受不到，心中回荡的只有一种恶心的感觉，两者一对比，令人感慨。可以说，双星2的发售标志着falcom一个时代的结束，不仅仅是平台的转换，也是falcom出品策略的转换：之前falcom并没有把宝全压在轨迹身上，还能出些富有特色的游戏让人留下深刻印象，轨迹只是其中的一部分而已，在双星2之后就全是没完没了，令人乏味的轨迹了。

希望falcom这次的都市校园风格的动作游戏能带来新的体验，不然我也只好跟这个伴随自己长大的厂商说声再见，然后偶尔在老作品中回味一下当初的回忆了。

—————————————————————————————————————————————

18182259.review:
This is a surprisingly fun game, I say surprising as my initial reaction was a little lukewarm but the more I played the more the overall charm of the game won me over. 

You play Parin a spunky young girl who has come to stay with her grandfather while her parents are away. It quickly becomes apparent that there isn't much to do in the mining town where he lives, but Parin is soon sucked into an adventure to rescue a group of friendly monsters. The game is fairly light plotwise but its enough to drive things forward and the dialogue is often funny.

The games real draw is the action packed game play that requires good use of your drill and special moves to beat the crap out of a variety of foes. It features an interesting critical hit system that is linked to the games music, get the timing right and you will do extra damage. There are also some light platforming and puzzle solving elements. This is an update of an older game and it shows in the textures which are sometimes muddy and lack detail, overall though the art design is very good and Parin herself is well animated with a variety of expressions and idle animations that bring her to life.

 Bear with the slightly rough start and you will be rewarded with a game that is deeper than it first appears.

Pros:
Charm in spades
Amusing dialogue
Fun action RPG-lite gameplay
Some good music
Good art design

Cons: 
Dated textures
Camera can be touchy in confined spaces

7.5 out of 10 and well worth the $10 entry fee.

17572903.review: Gurumin is an action RPG by Falcom featuring a young girl named Parin who must go on an adventure to save the monster world.  As Parin you will make many monster friends while being tasked with helping them fix their world by tracking down items in all sorts of interesting environments.  The story is heartwarming in a childlike way as both your monster friends and bad guys all have interesting personalities and the well written script and professional voice acting really helps bring them to life.  Along the way you will bash evil monsters with an array of combat moves that you can unlock with money you find in each level area.  The combat is a combination of joystick twirling and timed button pressing, nothing revolutionary but it works well.  There are also platforming elements that you will use to navigate the terrain and search for hidden treasure, healing items and head pieces (hats, ribbons, etc) that you can equip to power Parin up in different ways.    Graphically Gurumin is somewhat blocky and basic, but it’s very colorful and each area you explore is filled with interesting inhabitants that evolve as you explore further, helping to reduce the repetition that often accompanies action RPG’s.  Playing thru Gurumin is like exploring a new park as a child who has a vivid  imagination; discovering monsters, avoiding the lava and having a grand old time in an adventure that is light and fun with enough of a gaming challenge to feel satisfying.  Recommended for the young at heart, plays well with a game pad too.

17522840.review:
The game is a very cute Action RPG. It starts off with a girl (you) moving into her grandfathers house in a new city. Whilst exploring you find out there are no other kids in town which is conveniany cause you meet some new friends which call themselves monsters and they can only be seen by children. You get invited to check out their little monster town which soon afterwards gets attacked and you must now stop the dark mist from engulfing the world. You do this by getting their ancient drill weapon which no one has ever been able to pull out of the stone until now.

All in all it's an unoriginal story, but it makes up for it with fun gameplay mechanics and a cute art style.

The only issue however is the camera. You don't control it directly instead it "tries" to circle around you when it needs to. Which can cause some trouble, but you quickly get used to it and figure out how it works.

If you enjoyed classic PS2/Xbox era Cute Action RPG's you will probably find some fun with this game as well. Though I would recommend checking out some gameplay videos before hand to see what I meant by the camera to see if it's something you can handle.

17459426.review:
It starts out as an incredibly easy game, but the difficulty ramps up quickly. So, if you are bored in level 1, try to stick with it. I do agree that Hard should come unlocked

This game is full of charm, and there's lots of cuteness. Characters look at each-other when present, the main character will do poses like Sonic would do when you are idle, but never punishes you for it. There are lots of animation flourishes, but they don't get in the way of gameplay. They are done right because they aren't something that is player-initiated. There's also victory dances. Not enough games have victory dances. I miss that about Final Fantasy

The combat control is excellent. I can't tell if the 3D platforming is good or not due to the nature of 3D platforming. That part is frustrating. You don't feel like you have as much control of the character as you do in combat. Still, there's more combat than platforming, and the game is very lenient on screw-ups when you do platforming

As a budget game, I give this game a definite yes. I even say that it's worth above the budget level, but people may not buy it at more than $20. This feels like a Playstation-era game, and plays like one of the good ones.

There's also something Charlie Brown-esque about the voices that I kind-of like. It's nicely different than dubbed anime characters almost always having either that WWE or Wonder Woman voice, especially children. The awkward voicing kind-of works in this game, even though they could have acted some lines better when the lead character makes certain facial expressions

I also find the replay value of this game to be high. I hardly want to replay games, but I'm going another round at the hard difficulty. I don't do this often

16651950.review:
I haven't had this much fun playing a game in years! Gurumin really holds true to some older traditions in games.

My favorite things about this game are the very easy learning curve, the replay value, the light-hearted atmosphere, and the characters. Anyone, regardless of age, can pick up and learn how to play very easily. There are still parts that challenge you to master, such as the critical hit system going with the beat of the music. Even without beating the game, there are areas and secrets you constantly find by replaying older stages with new equipment, such as being immune to water damage and being able to find a tunnel underwater. Then on top of that, the game has a bunch of endings and difficulties to unlock, all the while your stats per level are recorded, giving you the chance to compete with yourself. From the main character to the supporting ones, every character adds to this easy-going world. Even though there's this bad person running around and things look grim in the land, you don't feel that sense of urgency. It's just nice and calm, letting you take it on at your own pace.

If I had to summon up any negative things to say about this game, I might say that the beginning cutscenes can be a little lengthy. You can't skip them, but they are important in understanding the story. Sometimes, you'll notice that the lip-sync is not correct, and the characters often move their mouths longer than they actually talk. Then again, that goes to show you how hard I have to look to find things to complain about in this game. 

Overall, my only regret about this game is not playing it sooner. I hope to see more great things from this publisher!

16004237.review:
Gurumin est un petit jeu d'action-aventure PSP datant de 2007 porté sur PC. C'est un jeu sympathique destiné à un jeune public de par son côté mignon, facile mais aussi car son côté répétitif peut rapidement lasser les gamers plus expérimentés.

Vous incarnez Parin (ou quelque soit le nom que vous lui donnez, moi je l'ai appelée Mirin, oui comme le saké de cuisine, ne me demandez pas pourquoi...) une petite fille qui vient vivre chez son grand-père. Alors qu'elle s'ennuie fermement dans cette ville elle va faire la rencontre de monstres qui deviendront ses amis. Mais les fantômes (les vrais méchants) vont détruire la ville des monstres et apporter de la tristesse qui se manifestera sous forme d'un épais brouillard recouvrant le monde. Parin/Mirin va alors se servir de sa foreuse légendaire pour vaincre les fantômes et aider les monstres à reconstruire leur village. 

En jeu la mission de Parin se traduit par un cycle qui se répétera tout au long de l'aventure :
1 - j'explore un donjon, une caverne ou une forêt en tuant les fantômes et en ramassant les pièces
2 - je récupère un meuble à la fin du niveau
3 - je rends le meuble à l'un des monstres
4 - le monstre est heureux et dissipe une partie du brouillard
5 - j'accède à un nouveau niveau
C'est très répétitif et lassant. Les niveaux ne sont pas très variés et on explore plusieurs fois des lieux similaires. Il y a parfois quelques énigmes à résoudre mais elles sont bien trop simplistes pour attiser notre intérêt. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=448729837 On passera d'ailleurs pas mal de son temps à farmer des jarres pleines de pièces... 

Pour parer à cette monotonie on ira faire un tour en ville de temps en temps histoire d'améliorer sa foreuse en apprenant de nouveaux mouvements, d'acheter des chapeaux, d'améliorer ces chapeaux ou de faire le plein de chocolats et gâteaux pour restaurer sa santé. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=448730487 Mais la ville est très petite, il n'y a pas grand chose à faire : 2 magasins, 5 PNJ et un chien, voilà, c'est tout. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=446470011 Au niveau du gameplay, si comme moi on joue à la manette, on saute avec B, on tape avec A et on dashe avec X. En combinant les touches et selon les attaques achetées auprès du moustachu pédophile en ville on pourra effectuer des attaques spéciales. Les [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=446471346]notes de musique en haut de l'écran permettent d'effectuer des coups critiques si on est bien synchro.[/url] La foreuse possède 3 niveaux qui augmentent ou baissent selon si vous vous faites toucher ou si vous effectuez des attaques critiques. Chaque niveau gagné augmente la puissance de votre arme, bien entendu. 

Concernant le B.O. du jeu sachez qu'il est en anglais et que les doublages sont bien réalisés. La musique du jeu est à son image : répétitive. Entendre ce genre de musique pendant des heures n'est pas très agréable, allez-y [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R5lHG4Jv01U]écoutez[/url] !

Au final Gurumin est un petit jeu sympathique pour peu qu'on n'y joue pas plus de 2h d'affilée car il est lassant et parfois on fait une overdose de kawaii. Il y en a quand même pour 9-11h de jeu, pas plus heureusement car même si ce jeu est bon ça fait aussi du bien quand ça s'arrête !
