15866578.review:
Gurumin: A Monstrous Adventure, developed by Nihon Falcom, is a HD re-release of the 2004 Japan-only PC game, with Gurumin last seeing English storefronts on the PSP in 2007. 

As a result, as well as running on just about anything, Gurumin serves as a time-capsule of videogames before contemporary design trends. Aesthetically, it's an adorable adventure game that resembles games like Blinx the Time Sweeper, 40 Winks, Ape Escape or just about any simple platformer with action elements from the fifth generation that you can think of. 

Layout-wise, it's exactly what you'd think. There's about 25 levels, each 5-15 minutes long, several different minigames, a secret boss and more than enough regular bosses to keep you satiated. The plot is simple, charming, and ends on as sickening a saccharine note as you could possibly want, though not before a satisfying one-on-one beatdown to decide the world's fate. The game goes out of its way to avoid surprising you - it's a comforting, easing experience first and foremost, with enough enthusiasm and charisma for its own existence to keep you playing and wanting more.

There are other benefits from refusing to evolve into a world of DLC and microtransactions. From the secret unlockables (which I won't spoil, else they wouldn't be secrets) to the plethora of regular unlockables, to the surprising (and punishing!) extra difficulty modes - this is a game from before the era of DLC nickel and diming you on extra content that used to be a joy to unlock.

Combat was designed by the creators behind the legendary Ys series (pronounced "Ees"). It's relatively simple compared to hack n slash giants like DMC or Ninja Gaiden, and the moveset discourages playing stylishly so much as playing efficiently, but it's far from boring - which doesn't do a great job of selling it, but there's enough possibilities, from specials to being able to launch an enemy and juggle them until they explode, to keep you interested indefinitely given the burst nature of the level design. And on higher difficulty modes you'll be finding yourself playing with it in ways you wouldn't have thought to.

Gurumin is a game that lives up to its legacy, a legacy of games that existed to entertain you, not to pillage your pockets. It's a static pocket of quality and quantity content to be content with you. 

It's not perfect. There are some odd glitches - notably, that you need to avoid S-Ranking every single level in order to get the "S-Rank every single level" achievement. Which is odd. For a PC-original game, the control scheme is alien, and frightening. Not to say it's unplayable with the defaults, but I do heavily recommend using a gamepad. 

And then there's Hoccer. Hoccer is a minigame I needn't say much about. Hoccer is a minigame you will discover for yourself. Hoccer will destroy you, as it destroyed me, and legions of other players before us. Accept your defeat and move on. Let Motoro have his win, it's not worth it. The Horror of Hoccer.

There's also some content missing that the PSP version has - some costume unlockables and such. Keep that in mind. It's nothing major.

Gurumin is well worth your time and money, and doesn't pray on your nostalgia. It shows you why you had nostalgia for what it represented in the first place. 

All it takes is a drill, and you're off on a monstrous adventure.

15572836.review:
MUH DRILLZ!

I'll get straight to the point: this game will definitely drill its way into your heart. *pause for laughter or groans*

*ahem* now that I have you either groaning from the pun or laughing your ass off, I'll start the real review.

This game comes to steam years later from the initial release in japan back in 2004, which got ported to PSP in June of 2006, made a north american appearance in 2007, and got an original PC release worldwide on steam.  From my point of view, everything about this game is great, with just a few minor complaints I have, which I will get to in this review.

Graphics: 9/10 - The graphics remind me of early playstation games such as Brave Fencer Musashi.  They get the job done, vibrant, and great use of color.  You can also tell it makes great use of cell-shading, but the characters do tend to look a little too simplistic.  Overall, however, this game looks great.

Gameplay: 9.5/10 - The game plays very well, and that's as much as I can say about it right now as I've only just started playing this game.  I will definitely update when the time comes, but one minor complaint: so far, I haven't really run into any boss fights. EDIT: Just ran into my first boss fight, and lemmie tell ya, they can really drill it to ya -pause again for laughs or groans-.  They're challenging, but fair.  It at least gives you time to use healing items and not have them clobber you as you do so.  Overall, the boss fights are great and vibrant.

Controls: 8/10 - Here's where I have to make a few complaints about controls here.  Some of the moves aren't very clear on what to do, especially if you're using a gamepad (or xbox 360/XBOne controller) for control.  The instructions are strictly PC oriented with no mention of what to do with the gamepad.  I would complain about it more, if it weren't for the fact that you learn pretty quickly what buttons do what move, so it's no big issue and the controls can be customized*.  
However, the controls do the job well, either way.  The jump controls are interesting, but can get a little frustrating, especially having to make platform jumps.  Fortunately, the shadow effects will help you, and you can angle the camera any way you please (right stick for xbox 360 controllers).  The inclusion of timed hits to the beat of the music with the beat bar displayed on screen is a wonderful addition.  If you've mastered Crypt of the Necrodancer, you'll definitely find that getting critical hits via the beat of the music to be very easy and fun.

Sound: 9/10 - The music, even though you can tell it's synthesizer, is VERY well done.  The english voice acting is a bit cheesy, but works anyways.  The music is upbeat and well composed, in my opinion.  You'll need to get that tempo down if you want to do critical hit damage, but the timing of each beat is precise and works very well.

Overall: 9.25/10 - This game is definitely a title for platform gamers to really dig into -pause for groans or laughter-.  Hopefully, we'll see some patches released to fix some of the issues, but overall, I recommend this game for anyone who loves a good platform game.


*At least the options to do that are up, but I've seen some forum posts about the game not running because options got changed.  Hopefully, this gets patched soon, as I did suffer the same thing when I tried to change around a few options.  Should you find your game not starting up, just hit the restore defaults button on the windows menu screen that comes up and it'll start normally again.  I have successfully changed a few options after having do to this, but kept it to just force feedback and maybe one other thing.

Very sweet experience that has been missing from video games from some time. If you have been raised on older consoles and still remember the mediocre yet charming titles that the Japanese developers churned out at that time do not miss Gurumin.

The game itself is a laid-back action 'RPG' about a young that has moved to a remote village to live with her grandpa only to find new friends in and adventures with... monsters living next to the village. 

Now, this was originally a early-2000's-PC-turned-PSP game so the levels themselves are rather short and the optional ones are reverse-copies yet are still enjoyable to traverse to and fro. The controls are not perfect but the porting Team is very helpful though and updates the game with new, requested PC-oriented features like button re-mapping etc. The game, obviously, runs very well and should budge even on toasters.

If your sick of the Assassin's, Duties, and other lifeless products get Gurumin - a result of nerdy love for video games, no more and no less.

15512347.review:
[h1]Gurumin: A Mostrtous Adventure is an action platformer who uses a drill to pierce the phantom menaces, to save her monster friends. [/h1] 

For those who do not know, this game originally came to the PC in 2004, but was a Japanese exclusive. Later around 2006~2007, there was a PSP port which was the first time the game was found outside of Japan. Fortunately, [i]this is a port of the original PC version with redone voicework[/i].

In Gurumin, you play as little Parin who came by an old mining town to live with her grandpa for a while. Walking around, she quickly realizes she's inside a town with no kids around her age to play with. She eventually makes contact with monsters, whom only can be seen by children. She is then invited to their village where they hang out.The plot starts as [b]all of Parin's monster friends are kidnapped by Phantoms, and she must go and rescue them because the bad guy said so[/b].

Gurumin can be played with gamepad or keyboard + mouse and as an experienced player, [b]I recommend playing with a controller[/b]. [i]Due to how the keyboard and mouse controls are built, it is pretty difficult to make precision jumps in this game; a must for platforming segments.[/i]

Combat is pretty simple. You bash a single button to attack and create small combos. There's a dodge button, and there's also a critical hit mechanic that lets [i]you deal extra damage if you time your attack with the rhythm of the music.[/i]

Gurumin's special weapon (the drill you see in pretty much all of those pictures) does essentially what you'd expect: [b]You drill things[/b]. Cracked walls, trees, various props in stages, special switches, and even armored enemies to remove the obstacles in your way.

Optimizaiton wise, [b]they really haven't done anything to enhance the game since the original 2004 release, except add support for 16:9 resolutions[/b]. The game runs pretty easily on almost any hardware (I'm pretty confident even Intel HD GPUs could handle this). The 16:9 resolution support however doesn't feel neat, as the UI does appear like it was just stretched from the largest original supported resolution (1280 x 1024).

I'll complain that [i]the default difficulty is a little too easy, but you can unlock harder difficulties later on[/i]. Unlocking harder difficulties requires completing the game on a previous difficulty. If you want to go through all that trouble, it's quite a challenge on "Happy" mode.

Overall, [b]Gurumin is a fun game, but it's a pain to get to the actual challenge difficulties[/b]. I originally played it on my PSP back in the day, was so amazed that there was a PC port, I bought the original Japanese version for PC. I was able to paste in the original Japanese audio (just my personal preference) into the Steam version fairly easy.

15472837.review:
Overall I would recommend this game. At $10 it's really hard not to; there are many games released nowadays without half the charm and without much of the same level content for a far higher price. Gurumin is not without its flaws, but I don't think the flaws are significant enough to outweigh the positives.

While the game is classified here as an Action RPG, I would argue against the RPG part of that. Is an RPG a game where your choices as your character define the world and set you on different story paths? This game doesn't do that (there are two endings available, but it's based on percentage of completion and not any choices made throughout the story, because there are none). Is it being able to assign points to various attributes like Strength, Charisma, etc.? This game doesn't do that; in fact, the only direct statistical upgrades for your character are health point increases after bosses, similar to what you would find in a Legend of Zelda title. What the game DOES have is an impressive array of hats that alter various aspects of your character (more damaging attacks, less damage taken, show treasure chests on the minimap, etc.), but Team Fortress 2 has that and I wouldn't classify that as an RPG either. I can't see ANY mention of the musical side of this game ANYWHERE on the Steam page which is very strange; I'd classify this game as a Musical Action game, if that's even a genre that exists.

The game places a fairly high priority in platforming, especially later in the game, and that is I think Gurumin's greatest weakness. Parin's jumps are a little hard to control, and her shadow is often not pronounced enough to tell exactly where she is located over sometimes excessively small platforms. The spastic camera, which refuses to stay put and constantly tries to center itself behind Parin, certainly doesn't help matters. Why am I given a button to immediately center the camera behind Parin if the game does this automatically every time I start to move? If I move the camera, I want it in that position until I say otherwise; several of the game's tricky jumps would be made vastly more simple if only I could set the camera at Parin's side and leave it there until after the platforming section, but if this option is available then I never found it. In the end I usually resigned myself to platforming relying entirely on the minimap; at least with the minimap there was no ambiguity as to whether I was over a platform or not.

Combat, however, is enjoyable, even if it is a bit easy (note that I have only beaten the game on Normal, and that higher difficulties might actually be...difficult). The next few sections are going to be talking about combat since it has some nuances. Parin has a standard neutral attack string and a variation if you hold in a direction while attacking, but you probably won't often be using those. Parin's dodge is extremely long and forgiving, and she gets three of them in a row; I never timed it but it has to be at least 3 full seconds of invincibility which is pretty insane in a game like this. Beyond that, one of the first special attacks you get is an attack after the dodge, and you're ALSO invincible during that attack animation, which at higher ranks adds another second and a half or so. There's little reason not to simply spam this one special technique over and over until everything in the room is dead considering that the attack itself is extremely damaging and reaches over a very wide area. Certain enemies have shields or armor on and are impervious to attack, so the armor needs to be removed by utilizing Parin's charged drill attack (this seems to be its only purpose, as the damage the charged drill attack does is pathetic even compared to normal attacks), but after that you're free to attack in whatever way you wish. The game does add in elemental effects (fire, lightning, and ice) that can be changed at a whim. Fire burns enemies and causes damage (a fairly small amount) over time, lightning slows and paralyzes enemies, and ice freezes them in place. There is also a system in place where certain enemies take more or less damage from certain elements, but at least on Normal mode this is easily ignored and the damage reduction for using the wrong element is fairly insignificant. Elemental attacks are also used in several of the game's puzzles. The only non-special attack that I used often is her homing jump attack, which is not only very useful for attacking flying enemies but is also extremely accurate (fittingly enough) and does fairly high damage. It is also, coincidentally, absolutely vital for some minigames.

One thing to note is that all special attacks in this game are performed the exact same way; rotate the character either clockwise or counterclockwise and then attack.  Doing it without dodging/jumping performs a 360 spin, doing it during a dodge performs a projectile attack (this is the room cleaner I mentioned above), and doing it during a jump performs a slam. I used a PS2-type controller, and the game is very forgiving with its detection of turns. It is, in fact, TOO forgiving, and I can't count the number of times I was jumping during platforming to attack an enemy and found myself plummeting straight into an abyss.

The last thing I have to talk about concerning combat is the drill meter. Parin uses a drill as her weapon. The drill has 4 levels (the game only counts 3 but I'll explain why I say it has 4). The higher the level of the drill, the more damage it does (some special attacks also change animations depending on its level). When the bar is filled to max you get a projectile attack every time you swing the drill; the game counts this as part of the 3rd drill level but since it's only actually available with a FILLED 3rd level and not just IN the 3rd level I count it as its own level. Now, how do you increase the drill level? The standard way is to get critical hits, and this is where the music minigame comes into play. It's actually so important a consideration in the game that I'm surprised Gurumin isn't called a Music Action game. At the top of the screen is a bar that acts as a metronome for the current music; if you time your strikes with the metronome you get critical hits, and every 100 critical hits gives you a drill level. There are also items and certain areas within stages you can use to increase your drill level, but both of these are fairly rare and for the most part you'll be relying on critical hits. This is why I say its strange the musical side of the game is so underplayed on the Steam store page.

As for music and sound...music is good. I can't think of a single song I disliked and there were several I would actually nod my head to as they played. As fits the game most of them are fast-paced and quite a few are cheery (sometimes a little overly cheery) but they didn't grate on my nerves. The sound effects are fairly simplistic, but it isn't as though this is a complicated, deep game or story so it fits the tone well. What I WILL complain about is the voice acting. It's sub-par to downright awful all across the board. I'm running out of space but suffice it to say that I didn't like anyone.

The story is cookie-cutter and saccharine (it involves giving monsters furniture to make them happy so that their happiness drives away the darkness. No, I am not oversimplifying it), and though I rolled my eyes during much of it I never hated it. Characterization is rather sparse, but then I don't think anyone came into this game expecting Catcher in the Rye.

I spent a fair amount of time complaining during this review, but the main thing to take away from this is that while the combat was simple I enjoyed it. The VAST majority of the game focuses on the combat. I didn't like the platforming but in the end the platforming is little more than how you get from one combat arena to the other. Overall I really enjoyed the game, and I heartily recommend it. It's a good game.

15464796.review:
Nie mam ochoty poświęcać tej grze więcej czasu jednak bez problemu wystawię jej ocenę pozytywną. 


To port starego już tytułu z PSP który pierwotnie w 2004 roku wyszedł na PC jedynie na terenie Japonii. Tak długą w czasie i przestrzeni drogę muszą przejść japońskie perełki żeby mógł się nimi zachwycić 'cały świat'.

Gurumin to przygodowa platformówka oraz gra akcji z elementami rpg. Znajdziemy tu tradycyjnie pokonywane w widoku TPP poziomy 3D testujące naszą zręczność w ruchu i w walce, skromny system rpg odpowiadający za rozwój postaci i zbieranie przedmiotów oraz sporą ilość dialogów, filmików czy cut scenek które przedstawią nam opowiadaną w grze historię. 
Wszystko to podane tylko i wyłącznie w sosie z japońszczyzny. Gra wręcz ocieka klimatem japońskiego anime oraz tym znanym z często podobnych jrpg'ów. Mamy więc dziwne stwory, duże oczy, małą dziewczynkę jako bohaterkę, płytkie rozmowy o niczym itp pretensjonalne klisze z których gatunek słynie :)
Mimo tego wszystko to tworzy całkiem przyjemną całość, choć na wspomniane klimaty mające korzenie w japońskiej popkulturze trzeba mieć jakąkolwiek tolerancję, nie mówiąc o tym że najlepiej je po prostu lubić.

Grafika jest słaba i skromna, nie spełnia żadnych standardów obecnych czasów ale trzeba pamiętać że to projekt mający ponad 10 lat. Całość może się podobać jeśli ktoś nie ma wyłącznie dużych wymagań bo sam projekt graficzny broni się nieźle. Mi w każdym razie nie przeszkadzało że gra wygląda jak tytuł z innej epoki.
Udźwiękowienie co najmniej dobre a może nawet więcej. Dobrze wypadają głosy aktorów co przy sporej ilości dialogów ma znaczenie. Muzyka i dźwięki także są ok spełniając wysokie standardy japońskich gier tego typu.

Jedyny duży kłopot jest ze sterowaniem, prawdopodobnie pad rozwiązuje wszelkie problemy, jednak mi o dziwo w końcu grało się nawet przyjemnie za pomocą myszy oraz jedynie czterech klawiszy klawiaturowych (shift, z, x, c). Finalnie więc myszą klikałem jak w h'n's, wchodziłem w interakcję z otoczeniem itd, a na klawiaturze skakałem, atakowałem czy operowałem w menu. Dla mniej wprawionych graczy może to jednak stanowić przeszkodę, sterowanie jest niełatwe albo inaczej - nieintuicyjne, niedzisiejsze. Na szczęście tempo całej rozgrywki jest przyjemnie powolne więc nie ma też potrzeby zbytniej gimnastyki palców.
Druga, mniejsza już wada, to niezgrabne i niewygodne menu konfiguracji poza grą. Widziałem że nad jednym i drugim ludzie odpowiedzialni za przejście gry przez Greenlight i wypuszczenie na Steamie w jakimś tam stopniu pracują, także można liczyć na drobne zmiany. 

Grę polecam fanom platformówek bo sporo czasu spędzimy tu na eksploracji poziomów jak w typowej, choć bardzo prostej w swojej strukturze grze TPP. Zastrzegam jednak że jest tu trochę elementów rpg oraz całkiem dużo elementów fabularnych, dialogów i cut scenek. Wszystko zaś, od fabuły, przez stylistykę świata i postaci aż po elementy platformowe to zdecydowanie czysta japońszczyzna i zasiadając do zabawy już na starcie musimy wyrazić na to zgodę. 
Łącząc ze sobą to wszystko powstaje bardzo nietypowa jak na PC mieszanka kilku gatunków. Każdy kto tęskni to gier rodem z Kraju Kwitnącej Wiśni zdecydowanie powinien sięgnąć po Gurumin: A Monstrous Adventure i raczej nie powinien być zawiedziony tym co otrzyma. 

W końcu dowolny tytuł z PSP oceniany tam na 75/100, na blaszakach wciąż stanowi sporą ciekawostkę. A dla wielu perełkę obok której nie można przejść obojętnie.

15362818.review:
Received for free from the official steam group promo.

A simple action-adventure (with a limited RPG elements) with okay graphics, decent animations/sound, and a story from a child's POV. Controls are usually fine, and the game engine physics allows you to kinda wallrun if you jump towards a wall, which looks pretty funny. You can manually resize the game window, which is pretty handy.

Dungeons are fun enough to run through, but don't expect too many innovations- it sticks to a very basic formula. You go room by room, killing all enemies, breaking all pots, opening all chests, and doing simple puzzles. At the end of a dungeon, you get one item to return to the monster village (which then unlocks more dungeons). You might even notice it reuses rooms a couple times in different dungeons with a little twist (like flipped). 

There are several minigames of varying quality. The most annoying is the 3v3 football/soccer one in which you can't control/dribble the ball, only hit it with attacks. If you try to play it like a normal sports game you'll be frustrated since most likely you'll never score a goal yourself. Just do locked-on jump attacks on the ball and it'll automatically hit it towards the enemy goal instead of straight ahead. You can just play defense and your AI ally will eventually get enough goals in.

Enemies aren't too hard, and you're free to switch between the three elements (for enemy weaknesses) and your head gear (for your resistances) in combat to finish them quickly. Bosses are pretty straightforward and in normal difficulty can be brute forced with healing items if you just want to run up and slash.

If you enjoy this basic formula, a childlike/innocent story, and the visuals this game might be for you. Otherwise, there are other action-RPGs that might be more tailored to your tastes.

15302494.review:
Picked this up when I saw it on Steam! I did not realize they even planned a port for it. the PSP is starting to age and I am glad I still get to play classics (ish) like this on a more powerful system.

First off, having played this to the bone on the PSP, I can address its content immediately and compare what I've experience in the PC port afterwards.

+Solid action platformer
+Engaging enemy variations (strategy cap must be on!)
+RPG/level elements
+Replayability
+Decently lengthed game (especially for completionists)
+Fun and memorable characters (most are some just add some spice to the setting)
+Great voice acting for the time period of its deveopment (espesially since its in english)
+Made by Falcom, the genius behind the Ys franchise and the early Legend of Heroes games

-Simple camera mechanics sometimes lag behind gameplay
-New Game + requires collecting items again (not necessarily a bad thing, it does add a "replayability" aspect than a God Mode)
-Completing the game 100% will take a lot of effort, some skill and back tracking
-Some progression aspects are vague (rarely)

Overall, this game was one of the rare gems in the PSP treasure trove along the lines of Ys: Napishtim (which Xseed is porting to PC this month), or Ys: Felghana (already on Steam!) in regards to genre. It has a very straightforward story that engages you with plot twists--sometimes unnecessary--that let you keep going. The leveling and gear system here also works well, not to mention customization options with all the different costumes. Gear levels carry over to NG+ given that they need to be reacquired. The characters are memorable and all play a role in the game. One particularly elusive cat, will definitely pique most players interest. The enemies are given so much variety throughout the game that merit a different approach everytime a new foe is encountered. Some can even get a tiny bit frustrating(-ly fun).

For the PC port, I think they only really need to adjust their config menu. Add support to the d-pad and R analog stick, for example. (I prefer using d-pads for platmormers like this because I feel more in control of direction. hehe) Video options also show little difference to me, noted that I'm not too keen on major graphic settings other than fps, res and vsync. I think that this game is aged and simple enough that the settings they give do not entirely make the game too noticably different on medium settings or ultra. The PC port, specifically, feels odd with the PSP type camera system, but perhaps it is more a complex fix than I give it credit for.

The games negatives aren't exactly negatives, per se. Nothing that holds back from enjoying the game entirely, but clearly show how this game was really built for more simpler control inputs. Noting that I play this game, like most of mine, using a gamepad.

If you've played this before, pick it up! If you haven't, PICK IT UP!! Otherwise, pick it up anyway! :D

15268019.review:
[i]You're my friend. And friends forgive each other.[/i]

[b]Gurumin: A Monstrous Adventure[/b] is an action platformer for PC released on 2004 by Nihon Falcom Corporation, of Ys and Trails in the Sky fame. Following the adventures of Parin, a small girl who moves to a mining town with her grandpa due to her parents being away for work, she finds out that there are no children to play with in the small town. That is until she finds a portal to a different world where monsters, whom only children can see, live.

The game is very reminiscent of old PSX era 3D platformers. You'll jump to platforms, kill baddies, break things to find goodies and all that good stuff. The combat in Gurumin, as expected from seasoned developer Falcom is pretty fun and fast. Parin can attack with her drill, roll, divekick into enemies and soon enough unlock special abilities performed by doing motions on the controller. The RPG branding in this game is pretty misled, the only customization you'll be able to do on Parin is equip her with different (silly) hats to add passive effects and unlocking new moves. Each hat can be upgraded with "Junk" that falls from armored enemies and can be upgraded up to three times. Your drill levels up as you connect Critical Hits (landed by hitting in sync with the music's rhythm) or dig in patches of dirt and levels down when you are damaged, similar to Cave Story. Eventually you'll gain access to elemental parts that can be imbued into your drill and as expected some enemies will be resistant or weak to certain elements.

As far as difficulty goes, Gurumin never offers much of a challenge save for some bosses here and there that require a bit more strategy. The game is pretty straightforward but offers plenty of things as unlockables to add replayability. You are evaluated after every stage based on your performance on time, enemies defeated, jars broken and chests found and these award you medals. Notably, Gold and Platinum Medals are used to unlock special items, so some practice might be needed for those stages. There are also some items that when given to monsters, not only allows you to watch some hilarious exchange of dialogue but also unlocks wallpapers. After beating the game in any difficulty, a new one is unlocked as well as an outfit for Parin. Difficulties range from mind-numbingly easy to sadistically hard.

Graphically, Gurumin looks pretty well despite the dated 2004 graphics. Using a cute cel-shading that reminds one of [i]Mega Man Legends[/i] and a colorful palette that manages to not be a complete eyesore, the game oozes charm. However, this being one of Falcom's first full 3D games there are places where the quality isn't high, most notably in character animations during cutscenes which (even in current Falcom games) look robotic and unnatural. Musically the game delivers, it's not Falcom Sound Team jdk's finest work but it has a nice slew of catchy tunes, stepping into awesome territory as the game progresses into its final moments. Mastiff has only offered us the English dub for voices which is pretty mediocre to be honest, however as a player of the original japanese version I didn't find this to be much of an issue as the original voice acting was pretty amateurish itself.

The worst part of Gurumin, however lies in the technical aspects. Not much has been changed from the original 2004 release in terms of configuration, so we're offered a tight handful of graphical and controller options. The keyboard control options in particular is pretty restrictive offering only a handful of keys enabled for use, while it is doable to play the game with a keyboard a controller is highly recommended. The game is also hard locked at 30 FPS, same as the original japanese version with currently no workaround to make it work at a higher framerate, only a handful of (apparently not working) antialiasing and texture filtering options and only a small number of screen resolutions. Those used to XSEED's improvements in other Falcom PC games might be disappointed here.

As previously mentioned, the game is reminiscent of early 3D platformers... even the bad parts. The camera has a habit of moving itself into awkward positions, the physics engine works kinda iffy sometimes making you miss some easy jumps, there is no lock-on for enemies, even though you can adjust the camera to focus the enemy it doesn't work as expected sometimes. Controller inputs are also somewhat loose, as I found myself executing a Downward Lunge accidentally even though I never input the full circle motion required for it.

In spite of its shortcomings, Gurumin is still a charming and lovely experience that is just plain fun to play, and a rather lengthy one for a platformer clocking at around 8-12 hours of gameplay, not including the optional dungeon and finding some hidden knick-knacks. If you don't mind the limited configuration options, Gurumin is worthy to be picked up during a sale at least and guaranteed to satisfy any platformer fan.

EDIT: Unlocks appear not to be working. Hold on to your money for a while.

15233014.review:
《Gurumin: A Monstrous Adventure》是一款由日本遊戲廠商Falcom製作發行的動作冒險遊戲，本作最早於2004年聖誕節在PC平台上發售，北美地區的發售日晚了日本地區三年之久，2006年時本作更登上了攜帶型掌機PSP平台，成為一款在日本國內頗具知名度的作品。遊戲故事劇情是在敘說女主角Parin的雙親在外地進行挖掘古物工作，將自己女兒託付給爺爺照顧，剛來到陌生的村莊就發現了一名被狗騷擾神秘女孩，路見不平的Parin很快就嚇跑了狗，上前查問狀況之後才發現那名女孩其實是只能被孩童看見的幽靈，為了感謝救命之恩，他被邀請到幽靈們居住的村莊，同時也結識了許多幽靈朋友，不過和平的日子沒有持續很久，被稱為幻影的神秘勢力突然出現，將幽靈村莊的居民們一一綁架，為了拯救自己的朋友，Parin拔起了傳說的鑽頭武器，挺身對抗心懷不軌的幻影王子。


日本遊戲廠商Falcom製作發行的動作冒險遊戲大多都是屬於主線任務簡短、重複遊玩性高、整體難度偏高的作品，《Gurumin: A Monstrous Adventure》成襲了這三項傳統，遊戲的主線劇情非常簡短，像筆者這種單一關卡可以失敗三次的玩家也能在八個小時左右打到最終關，不過玩家如果想要強化所有裝備與解鎖特殊服裝的話，可是要花上三十五小時以上的遊戲時間才能順利達成這項目標。如果你是動作遊戲的生手，不用擔心本作難度過高會影響遊戲樂趣，你可以先從初學者難度訓練自己的技術，等到技術熟練後就能挑戰高難度的關卡，打出優秀的關卡評價，同時解鎖不同種類的服飾來打扮並強化自己的人物，體驗遊戲樂趣與完成挑戰的成就感。

15209074.review:
A fun, super-charming 3D action game.  You get a bunch of different headgear to serve as equipment, with some shared and some unique benefits, like the gas mask protects from poison gas, goggles from water damage, etc.  Headgear can be leveled up to improve their effects and add new ones like damage reduction and damage multipliers. You only have a drill as a weapon, with three exchangeable elemental parts but they all play the mostly the same aside from some enemies being weak to different elements.  There's a bunch of special moves you unlock through buying parts for your drill and they're all easy enough to perform.

The gameplay is separated into short dungeon crawls, with no area being any longer than twenty minutes or so.  Each area has two regular stages, then a boss, then two more "secret" stages that can be unlocked by solving some type of riddle.  There's enough stages to give the game a solid length and it ends before becoming tedious.

Being a 3D action/platformer, the camera control can be a bit finicky, especially since the game doesn't an option to map the right analog stick on the controller as camera control, instead defaulting to the shoulder bumpers.  You get used to it after a while though, and it's never too big of a problem.  The first platforming section with water is probably the worst in the game for various reasons, so don't fear if you flub it up a bunch.  There's not a ton of precise platforming here.  Otherwise, the game controls well.  Parin moves fast and attacks fast.  If you've played previous Falcom games, you already know they know how to do fast-paced action really well.  The music and sound effects are good, too, as you'd expect from a Falcom game.

As for the story/voice acting stuff, it's bleh and generic for the most part, but the lead character has a good dub and the game has a ton of little charming touches that overshadow the problems.  NPC dialogue is pretty fun and you can examine a bunch of stuff in-game and Parin will comment on it.  The game's artstlye has aged really well, so even though it's technically unimpressive, the game never really looks bad due to a strong stylistic foundation.

For those that like to replay/master rank games, there's a ton here, like multiple unlockable difficulties and extra headgear/costumes to find and even a secret playable character.  It you don't care about that kind of thing, it can be safely ignored without hurting your experience. 

As for the port, it's a bit of a mixed bag at this point.  I'd played it 1080p, and there was a constant white line along the top of the screen, only really noticeable during the letterboxed cinematics but it's there.  There's also appears to be issues with new game+ stuff unlocking incorrectly, as I had one of the extras upon starting up a new game+, but it seemed to have disappeared forever after quitting the game and reloading.  I imagine these types of bugs will be fixed in the near future.

In short, if you're looking for a fast-paced, light-hearted 3D action game, Gurumin is what you're looking for, especially considering how few likeminded games like this there are available on PC.

15201328.review: This game is actually really cool. If you aren't super into rpg's, don't be discouraged to buy this game. A game that this plays very similar to would be (to a very small extent) Kingdom Hearts. But comparing this game to another doesn't do it justice. Some might complain that this is just a flatout port of the psp game. They would be right. But here's the thing. There was nothing wrong with the psp game to begin with, so what do you really need to change? Imagine this like a PS2 launch game that wasn't. It gives me the same vibe I got playing Ratchet and Clank or the aforementioned Kingdom Hearts. If you grew up with the PS2 (which sounds crazy to guys in their mid 20's), then I totally think you'll feel the same. Now this game is not neccesarily polished. There are some (kind of hilarious) graphical hiccups such as what looks like parkouring ever corner you see when not grabbing on a ledge. But this game has some wicked cool things about it. For example, you have a seperate currency system for upgrading equipment that you get from battling monsters. The game rewards you for searching around for money by giving you medals depending on how many jars and chests you get. You can even spend those medals on items that will help you out later on. There's also a pretty cool combat system. Although the controls can be a bit wonkey with my Xbox 360 controller, for the most part you can get the job done pretty well. The fact that your drill levels up instead of you kind of makes this game feel less and less like a traditional RPG (which I normally don't like). The voice acting is good. That is except the main character. You can obviously tell she's new and some points makes you want to cringe with her acting. She's not terrible though, just below average. The music is good but kind of repetitive. It didn't get on my nerves though, but if you showed me a song from the game and didn't say it was from the game I'd probably just think it was from some random rpg. Overall, I say get this game if you are a fan of non-traditional rpgs and games like Kingdom Hearts. Either way though, I'm not complaining. I got it for free because I met the requirements for the greenlight campaign.

15165020.review:
A cute Ys-style game from Falcom, originally released for PC in 2004 and ported to the PSP in 2007. The game's environments and BGM are quite relaxing, as you wander about the town, helping characters solve their problems. The voice dub is competent, if goofy in a way, and the characters are very well-drawn and animated. The art is very well done. Almost all of the various headgear and costumes you acquire along the way fit Parin rather nicely.

There is a lot of attention to detail in this game. Stand Parin the protagonist next to a character dancing to his boombox and she will join right in. Characters go about their lives in town and might wander in and out of different buildings if you are looking for them. Parin in particular is full of personality, from the way she acts and how she responds to other characters.

Gameplay-wise, combat is smooth, and the invincibility frames you get are very generous. It's not nearly as difficult as Ys, but some opponents are notably tougher than the rest though, otherwise this is a very child-friendly game. There are plenty of secrets to find and things to unlock. Truly mastering a stage would mean getting S triple + rank, so there is plenty to do.

Criticisms incude: keyboard key-binding options are not the best and camera control with a controller is non-existent. The option for Japanese audio would have been nice, but Mastiff (the localization company) is looking into both of these at time of writing. The higher difficulty levels also need to be unlocked first.

Games with unadulterated charm are rare these days, so give it a whirl if you like the genre.

15162834.review:
Gurumin is an action platformer developed by Falcom in 2003.   The project was helmed by the same group who made Zwei but is about a girl who uses a drill to defeat enemies and dig through structures instead of using a partner to shoot magic and relies on eating to boost stats.   This title was also made when Nihon Falcom was sorta in a rut and didn't find financial success to run on until Sora no Kiseki Second Chapter.  This really shows now adays as Gurumin looks no better than a N64 game with improved textures to dabble with. 

The game's still fun, albeit very very simple.   The music is kinda boring, the enemies are slow and easy, the map design is kinda rudamentary.  All and all this seems like a simple game whipped up by a studio and dev team to just clear some technical checkpoints.  This is a Banjo Kazooie/Mario 64/Ape Escape/Crash Bandicoot clone that while fun is just lacking in so many areas. 

It's charming, cheap, and worth a try.   Give it a whirl if you like the team behind it, but I wouldn't really say get it if you're looking to revist the era where action platformers dominated the market because this is not the next Jet Force Gemini.

15158707.review:
既然是FALCOM的游戏，先日常黑一下社长
近藤你敢不敢不夹私货的复刻一下PC98版朱红血那款神作，那玩意不比你现在拿十年前的引擎搞什么HD搞什么EVO逗死忠玩强100倍……早川正的修行近藤这辈子也赶不上了……2000年那版夹带大量私货的win版朱红血简直没法看……
------------------------------------------------------------------
咳咳，正题
这游戏，玩多了falcom游戏的人应该不陌生，解谜，动作，RPG三位一体的体系是falcom玩了30年的把戏，说句不太好听的，win时代以后同质化严重，只不过有的谜题多点，有的偏动作多点，有的RPG成分多点，总之是脱离不了铁三角了。但是falcom好像平衡其间关系的就是做成不同的风格，YS风格传统王道动作重头，老双星和gurumin风格清新内容平衡（因为各种原因Z2至今没碰也没想碰就不谈了……），Xanadu next RPG成分很重风格方面装硬派（咦为什么有装这个字），不过也有那由多那样定位不明的……[strike] 虽然那由多很可爱就是了prpr [/strike]
说说Gurumin
首先风格上面我先口胡两句，这部作品确实戳萌点，帕琳原地不动有不下四种卖萌姿势，还有各种服装DIY也很棒- -[strike] 不过为什么回血还有裸飘，法老控其实有过居心不良要吸引萝莉控的想法？ [/strike]大部分角色虽然性格元素相对单一（其实你仔细看某几部轨迹里的角色性格也挺单一的，不过风格体现出来的区别就是一个是呆萌，一个是中二期二愣子），但是给人的感觉是清爽明快，反而也有了各自的萌点……童话故事本该如此
故事方面不多剧透了- -怕被打死……大体是说，我们的小主人公帕琳到了一个没有孩子的城镇里，却意外的发现了大人们看不到的幽灵，并与他们成了朋友，然后在危机降临时，小帕琳拔出传说中的钻头，开始了为了拯救朋友的大冒险的故事（听起来好像老套，其实结局还是很合理而又意外的）
游戏系统上面好像没什么可说的，虽然和Z1、某几代YS比起来其实系统区别不小，但是不知为什么同质化的感觉就是挺浓的，玩过Z系Y系还有那由多的应该都能秒懂……另外就本作而言需要注意的是，我用手柄打穿再试着用键鼠，结果感觉键鼠好反人类，是错觉么？
总体而言，是一个非常值得体验的游戏，这个价格我觉得刚刚好，风格有爱的请不要犹豫。
---------------------------------------------------------------
最后吐槽一下本地化（英语化）版本的感觉，由于还没体验完全，先说说现在的感觉吧
代理商良心了一把，挺感人的，居然上了英文配音，而且配音质量不错，确实不错
但是请原谅我打个不合时宜的比方…………
[strike] 南方公园黑暗四天王中的kenny说人话了！为什么！ [/strike]

15146719.review:
Originally a Japanese PC game released in 2004 later ported, and translated for the PSP in 2007.

Gurumin: A Monstrous Adventure can be looked at as a "Kids" version of a Ys game (another great ARPG series from Nihon Falcom).

This game is an Action RPG Platformer, with a unique addition that allows you to attack to the beat of the music playing for critical strikes. 

---

The game has a great clean and colorful look (but doesn't bleed out colors unnecessarily like other Japanese games), that still holds up well even today but now in 1080p, 60 frames.

***I'd really recommend turning off DoF as well as the Blur effect & BackBuffer (flickering in the title/main menu may occur with this one), to get rid of the "fuzzy" look many players are experiencing. Forcing AA & 16x AF on your control panel is also recommended.

The controls are responsive, and simple to use.
You simply go around Hack 'n' Slashing your enemies to the beat of the music with combos, while going through simple platforming and puzzles. Please bare in mind that when this game first came out, there was no xinput. Although gamepad support was added by Mastiff, you might need to configure your controller with the game config.

***But I can confirm that with a 360 controller or wrapper, you shouldn't need to do anything besides changing [Show Forward] & [Show Enemy] to the Stick Buttons.

The music was created by the Falcom Sound Team jdk internal band, which also made the original soundtracks for most of their releases (Ys series, The Legend of Heroes series, et cetera). So you can expect a great listen all throughout the game.


A must have for any ARPG lover, or Falcom fan.

This is a nice update of the Falcom classic. It is much more playable than it's PSP counterpart which Mastiff first brought overseas. The camera in that version was pushed in much too close to the player character, severely limiting your field of view. This update fixes that by not only going back to the PC original FOV, but also adds widescreen to the mix.

Works just fine on Windows 7 and XP. Theres an issue where the right-stick camera controls can't be mapped on directinput pads, but can be worked around by setting shoulder buttons to rotate the camera.  Another thing I noticed is the AA options either don't work at all or crash the game (@ 4x). I hardly noticed edge aliasing in-game anyway. 

Since posting this review, someone in the forums discovered that disabling certain options, like DOF, might allow AA to work. I haven't tested this.

15140220.review:
Edit: Most of this stuff is fixed now, so it's pretty good. I'll just leave the original review below for posterity.

The game might be good, but I'm not sure if it actually is, because this port is abysmal.

First, control mapping. You can't map anything to a gamepad's triggers, the right stick doesn't work in-game, and there's no D-pad support. Movement with a stick is awkward, as 99% of the stick's range is for walking while only fully pressed out is for running. For the keyboard, you can only pick from a small selection of keys made available to you, for some bizarre reason. You can't even properly play the game with just a gamepad, as the opening menus require you to hit enter on the keyboard, as the gamepad won't work for them.
The AA option simply doesn't work. Even forcing AA through video card settings hasn't worked for some people.
There are very few resolution options.
It's currently dub-only (though easy enough to mod).
Tutorials all display mouse & keyboard controls, even if you're using a gamepad.
Hell, just look at the forums, there's plenty more issues listed, and there's no need for me to copy paste what other people have already pointed out.

I've heard plenty of good things about Gurumin, and as a Falcom game I expect it to be quite good, but I can't possibly recommend it until the port is fixed.

15136861.review:
娱乐通出的中文版早在几年前就通关了两遍，前一阵子发现绿光上有投票免费领key的投票，就抱着+1的心态投了yes。当时以为这只是个将文本翻成英文的版本而已，没想到上个月看介绍视频的时候发现配音也换成了英文，尤其是里边帕琳的配音真是让我萌得不行，心态也一下子从+1变成了非常期待。今天游戏一放出来就赶紧下载下来试玩了一会，果然英文配音质量非常棒，尤其是帕琳那带点哑的萝莉音和皮诺的甜萝莉音，真是超萌啊，光是冲这一点就绝对值得再通关一遍。

除了配音以外，再说点和记忆中的中文版不太一样的地方。英文版一开始就开启了所有难度，我记得中文版原来是锁住一些难度的。进入游戏后，一开始就可以在衣柜处换上所有服装（我选择的是最简单的难度，其他难度开没开启不清楚），这真的是一个很方便的设定，原来的中文版想要收集全服装并不是一件轻松的事，而且一出来就可以使用泳装也大大降低了游戏难度。英文版在这方面做得确实比较体贴人。

虽然我的这份游戏是免费领的，但是优秀的英文配音和一些改良的设计还是值得喜欢这个游戏的老玩家+1收藏的。对于没有玩过游戏的新玩家来说，游戏本身的素质也绝对对得起它的价格。虽然它是一个2004年的游戏，但是它的趣味性并不输于现在的游戏。

最后说一点题外的，不知道是因为轨迹是近藤亲儿子还是什么别的原因，falcom这几年的游戏质量是越做越烂，除了没完没了的轨迹就是没完没了的轨迹，终于在闪轨这一代（1+2）来了次爆发，白开水（闪轨1）/屎（闪轨2）一样的剧情+乏味到极点的游戏流程几乎把牌子都砸了。这也是难免的事，当一个游戏公司不断在重复过去赚回忆钱而不思进取的时候，就离失败不远了，国内的几把逗比剑就是这么完蛋的，虽然falcom水平比国内几个逗比厂商水平高些不至于死掉，但轨迹系列估计也就这么烂尾了。今天重新玩到这个falcom在2004年发售的游戏，还是能感受到十足的趣味，再联想前一阵子刷逗比闪轨二周目，连一点趣味都感受不到，心中回荡的只有一种恶心的感觉，两者一对比，令人感慨。可以说，双星2的发售标志着falcom一个时代的结束，不仅仅是平台的转换，也是falcom出品策略的转换：之前falcom并没有把宝全压在轨迹身上，还能出些富有特色的游戏让人留下深刻印象，轨迹只是其中的一部分而已，在双星2之后就全是没完没了，令人乏味的轨迹了。

希望falcom这次的都市校园风格的动作游戏能带来新的体验，不然我也只好跟这个伴随自己长大的厂商说声再见，然后偶尔在老作品中回味一下当初的回忆了。

—————————————————————————————————————————————
有人反映说难度衣服什么的没有全部开启，我进游戏看了看，发现当初还开启的难度现在已经锁起来了，当时开的简单难度存档里的衣服也全部都锁起来了。

当时以为全部解锁的设定是英文版特意为之，毕竟游戏已经上市多年。现在看来这应该是bug。官方随后发布的几次补丁已经将这部分修改成和中文版一个样子了。

之前的错误判断可能会影响到看这个评测的人的决定，所以特别说明一下。

15135527.review:
一个很有趣的游戏，制作公司是制作了轨迹系列和伊苏系列的法老控(FALCOM)。《咕噜小天使》采用可爱漫画风格的角色扮演游戏。玩家在游戏中将扮演一位叫做帕琳的12岁小女孩，为了帮助善良的妖怪朋友，而使用钻子为武器，与邪恶的妖怪们对抗。 游戏的画面非常清新，人设也相当可爱。比起Falcom前几作游戏最大的突破就是加入了全程语音。几位声优的生动演出把游戏当中的主要人物的性格表现得淋漓尽致（有没有觉得女主棒读很萌萌哒，有木有！），特别是幽灵之家的每个成员说话都有不同的尾音，听起来非常的有趣。
另外，比起《伊苏》系列以战斗为主的游戏方式，《咕噜小天使》又添加了相当多的解密的成分，这一点类似于Falcom的另一经典游戏《ZWEI!!》（双星物语），不过其谜题的种类更加多样化，到时候玩家不仅要动手对抗敌人，而且还要开动脑筋去解开谜题。（以上全部抄袭百度百科）
                                                                                                                                                                     评测作者：腾讯网编辑

15133727.review:
This 3rd person Action/RPG is a delight on the eyes and ears as much as it is to play. From its adorable artstyle to quick vicious combat, Gurumin feels comfortable and approachable. The combat is based off rhythm, landing critical blows in a timed fashion. While dodging enemy attacks and traps. This makes the combat and combos dynamic and quick paced. The over all artstyle is extremely anime and cute. This may or may not throw some people off. At heart, Gurumin is a light-hearted game and never really takes itself seriously. That doesn't mean that the game is a casual experience. With five difficulties, mini-games and plenty of secrets to discover, there is plenty to satisfy those looking for a more deeper experience. With great voice acting, fantastic soundtrack. Gurumin is a great family friendly game. 

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/yE5UnMONfck
I hope you enjoy!
Martyr

15133670.review:
Before I say anything, know that I also recieved this game for free by helping it get greenlit. Having played it before on the PSP, I thought it really deserved a second chance to reach the masses.

As long as you don't expect too much from this game, you won't be disappointed. There's no real gimmick here like you'd see in most indie titles nowadays, keep in mind this did come out about a decade ago. It's very much a straight forward action-rpg, so what makes it worth picking up? The charm.

You might want to skip this one if you despise cutesy anime guff, unless your backlog of action titles is running dry. Everything, even the voice acting seems like it's straight out of a Saturday morning anime. Stylistaclly it reminds me of Mega Man Legends, or the Evolution series on Dreamcast and Gamecube. Graphically it also looks like a Dreamcast or Gamecube title, maybe an early PS2 game.

It seems like I'm bashing the gameplay itself but it's actually pretty solid, just don't expect anything you haven't seen before. There's a pretty basic (and therefore repetetive) combo system, but it's still pretty satisfying. At 10 bucks you could do much, MUCH worse.

Oh, and you can dress the main character up in a cute little monkey outfit. 

7.5/10 Would "aww" again.

Cute Game;

Voice acting is superb.
Story is as cheesy as you'd expect after seeing the trailer.
Rhythm Drilling = Crits which is kind of neat but not neccessary.
Couple neat puzzles but its nothing you haven't seen before.
Has secrets hidden here and there which give some stages some needed replay value
This is a very face value game if you think its cute- -you'll probably like it.



Keyboard controls are a bit awkward, for instance; 
Holding down right click and space bar at the same time makes your character appear to be doing a "Space jump" where she just kind of overs in position doing a lazy jumping jack if you move your cursor just a tad infront of her.

Controllers however seem to work just fine. (i use an xbox controller.)
 
This is a puzzle game which is also ironically its most challenging aspect; there are parts where it doesn't tell you where exactly to go next and so you must scavanger hunt. This can be semi-frustrating having you pace around in levels at random --or worse-- when you're in the right level and you miss exactly 1 breakable pot, chest or monster which ruins your S Rank which you need to acquire gold medals and "master" the stage.   Forcing you to retry the stage later.  Its one of those kinds of games but I'm just glad its not always easy.

[spoiler]Fun Story: I got semi-trolled by this game early on when they had you guess a password and i guessed it right away but turns out the password was case sensitive which is why it said it was incorrect.[/spoiler] 

[spoiler]After more playing; This game has all kinds of hats and costumes to unlock. Hats being very important as you will find yourself constantly switching them out while in the midst of your endeavor (one shows you where the ever-important loot is, one makes you immune to water damage, one makes you gain more coin, another hat for combat yadda yadda yadda..) I found myself switching to a hat to kill a monster then to another to pick up the coin then to another for the world traps but that's just me being nitpicky. [/spoiler]


If you're okay with an innocent sense of humor then I'd definitely give this game a shot. 

May your drill pierce the heavens; as Parin's cuteness has pierced my heart~

15131136.review:
A really good mix of Action RPG and platformer from the makers of classics like Ys and Trails in the Sky. You control a girl with a drill that will pierce the heavens and embark on an adventure to save friendly monsters from a bunch of bad monsters. The controls take a bit getting used to, and the camera, as usual, is a pain from time to time, but the game is entirely playable with just a mouse when you get the hang of it, and the gameplay is pretty damn good. The artstyle is very cutesy and colorful, full of life, and while the voice acting is what you would expect from the early 2000, the translation is  solid.

Overall, a game that you should give a try to. At 10 Euros or your regional equivalent, it's a freaking steal for what you get.

15130971.review:
I recently got this game through the promotion, so it was a free gift. I wanted to try this game out because I was tired of playing super serious games, and many reviews for the PSP version likened it to Zelda games. I'm interested in those, so I had a good outlook on this before it came out. 

First and foremost, this game is NOT friendly to keyboard users. The controls are very flighty, and you can't keybind with the normal WASD setup. You are given a tutorial at the start of the game that explains that you can use the right click to move (which is incredibly odd). The problem here is that the character likes to take wide turns. Jumping, something that many games includes, is fairly nice in this; except for that god awful sound effect. SPROING, SPROING, SPROING. Don't hold the space bar down, use X to jump. The camera controls don't work in some places, leading to a poor view at times. In the starter town, these controls are pretty annoying and almost off-putting.

Audio quality is varying. I understand that this game is meant for younger audiences, so I will approach it as such. As said above, the jumping mechanic includes a very annoying sound effect. VERY annoying. I'm not far into the game, but I'm almost positive that jumping will be required, so I'll be subject to the torturous sound when I need to progress with jumping. I could go on and on about how bad the sound effect is, but I'll leave it there. Music is charming and enjoyable, but it's incredibly loud. I've got the volume set to its absolute lowest, and it's still very loud. I've had to lower my computer's max volume just to get it to a reasonable level. As for voice acting, I apologize to any of her fans, but the voice actress for Parin just sounds so bad. She's unenthusiastic, and her dialogue sounds like she's just reading the script and nothing more. The grandfather at the start sounds so lively and cheery, and then Parin talks and sounds boring. I've read elsewhere that the PSP version has optional Japanese audio, but the Steam release does not. Either way, the voice acting is pretty weak. As I was wandering around the starter town, I suddenly hear a LOUD not-dog barking. Really irritating sound, AND loud. I didn't expect to get spooked by a cartoony game.

Characters are pretty cut and dry in terms of tropes. Parin, the heroine, is the peppy young female who is always cheery. Her grandfather, Hyperbollic, is the flighty and forgetful old mayor who's fun to talk to. Then there's Cyllinder. HOW DID THIS GET APPROVED? He's practically a pedophile with how he talks to Parin. It's incredibly creepy. The first monster you meet, Pino, is the generic cutesy "mascot" kind of character in the sense that she shows up out of nowhere, gets into trouble with a simple animal, and is rescued by a girl who is the only one who can see her. The monsters, prior to obtaining the drill, are all goofy critters that you'd expect from a child-friendy series. Other than the pedophile, the characters are all alright.

Gameplay...First off, I skip cinematics. The dialogue mixed with the ridiculous volume and bad voice acting are enough to get annoyed with. Thankfully that can be turned off so I don't hear them. Luckily, there's boards that explain what to do. In the first dungeon, you learn how to attack, push objects, and dodge. You also learn a move where you can stay airborne for as long as you jump and attack enemies. That's pretty enjoyable. One thing that bothered me at the start was the meter up top with the moving stars, but that was explained as the method for getting critical hits. Now things die too easily since I'm good at rhythm games. Still, it's a nice mechanic, and probably the one thing I really like so far. After the first dungeon, you meet another character named Popon, who uses a sword rather than a drill. I couldn't stand her voice, so I didn't play as her for more than a minute (I didn't close the game to turn off voices at this point). The most hilariously bad aspect is that you can't equip the goggles you're given at the start of the game. This may be because I run around in one of the alternate costumes, but still.

Disregarding all of the glaring flaws, the core game is enjoyable even if the controls are flighty. In my opinion, playing the game muted is best, but that's just me. The story isn't anything fantastic, and the characters aren't all that unique, but it's pretty fun for a time waster. I'd GREATLY suggest getting the PSP version instead, since this game was obviously made for controllers instead of keyboards. I'm only selecting "Yes" for recommending since there's no "Maybe" option.

Also, that wardrobe lets you wear a skimpy leopard costume. On a little girl. Thanks, Japan!

TL;DR - Fun Zelda-like game. However is held down by Questionable control scheme and 30fps lock.
